TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
It would destroy the historic village of Pitt town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1 per cent of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits that the people of other States.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatently discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80 per day in the other States. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
Use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of government standard costs at a level not less that the prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Student Residential Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the reduction in the subsidy to tertiary student residential colleges of twenty- five per cent announced in the Federal Budget will:

1. Increase the financial hardship already being experienced by Australian students. The cut in subsidies to colleges will undoubtedly increase fees for that accommodation in 1984. Many students will be forced out of tertiary education as they will not be able to meet these increased costs particularly as the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme only gained a maximum increase of $2.80 per week in the Federal Budget.

2. Decrease access to education for country students. Many country students live in college accommodation either to attend tertiary institutions in the metropolitan area or in regional centres. The cut in the subsidy to residential colleges will even further disadvantage this group of students who already have comparatively low participation rates in tertiary education.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to ensure:
1. That the full subsidy to student college accommodation is immediately restored.
2. That the Federal Government assume financial responsibility for all student college accommodation to prevent the planned closures of colleges in Victoria.
3. That two student representatives are appointed to the committee of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reviewing student housing.

4. That new forms of college accommodation are investigated which would be more appropriate to the needs of the current student population, i.e. accommodation appropriate for students with dependant children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectively showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recuirrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Manual Assistance Centre, Parkes
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Pariament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposal of Telecom Australia to close the Manual Assistance Centre at Parkes will severely disadvantage the Parkes community by:-
1. The loss of current enmployment and future employment opportunities and consequent loss of income to the district
2. The loss of a local 24 hour emergency service
3. The loss of local knowledge of telephonists being available to telephone users when traffic is routed to an exchange anywhere in the State
4. The loss of a local and personalized service provided especially to elderly and handicapped people.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senate will call on the Government to halt the closure pending a full and open inquiry into the needs and desires of affected subscribers and the full economic and social effects of the closure on this district, rural telephone subscribers and Telecom Australia employees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Pariament assembled : The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia and Electors of Victoria respectfully showeth:

That the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (Victoria) calls upon the Commonwealth Government to take appropriate action to reduce and, ultimately, abolish and prohibit the export of live sheep from Australia and replace it with a carcass only trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs or, alternatively, the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the announced decision by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr West, to refuse visas for the visits to Australia of Mr Kent Durr, a National Party member of the South African Parliament, and Mr Mahmoud Rajab, a member of the President's Council. I remind the Minister that I have, for years, been an unqualified opponent of the vicious practice of apartheid and that, in 1982, I made two visits to South Africa, had extensive discussions with members of all political parties and all racial groups and reported extensively to the Australian Government following such discussions. I ask, firstly, does the Minister not agree that the South African Government should be encouraged and indeed urged to develop its dialogue and increase its economic relations with neighbouring states in South Africa instead of a policy of isolation and military incursions? Secondly, should not Australian politicians and citizens concerned with the human rights of the great majority of South Africans have every opportunity to express their views to persons in authority in that unfortunate country? Thirdly, would not the Australian Government be better advised to increase communication and press on with the implementation of a code of conduct for Australian business in South Africa, which I have urged past governments and the present Government to implement and which the present Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, undertook to facilitate in his public statement of 5 June 1983?
—I suggest that the first part of the question be answered by the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inasmuch as this question involves the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I say that the decision to refuse entry to the two members of parliament from South Africa was based on the merits of their case. We had a situation in which applications for visas had been put forward on behalf of those two people. We had at the same time knowledge, via a letter which was distributed by the Ambassador for South Africa, Dr Dennis Worrall, and which was issued before any such decision had been made on the visas, that these two people, Mr Kent Durr and Mr Mahmoud Rajab, were coming to this country 'for a series of seminars of a confidential nature at which there would be no media coverage'. People were invited to attend and travel and accommodation expenses were offered to those people. It seemed quite clear to those who made this decision-and the decision was made on this individual case-that this was a propaganda exercise. Despite the claims of Mr Kent Durr that he would not be talking about apartheid, it is quite clear from the list of matters to be discussed at the seminar that that matter would be discussed. I remind honourable senators that the previous Government had a policy of opposing apartheid and opposing visits to this country by sportsmen, by representatives of sporting organisations and by those who wished to come here to propagandise in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: In future, as I think Senator Missen has implied, these matters will be looked at on a case by case basis. In the past people whose political views have not been the same as those of this Government have visited this country. But in this case, to permit the entry of two parliamentarians for them to advance arguments supporting the apartheid policies of the South African Government, we believe would not be in accordance with the policy of strong opposition to apartheid, a policy which, I add, was the policy of the previous Government. The matters raised by Senator Missen about the formation of a code of conduct for Australian businesses in South Africa and, for that matter, the development of a policy concerning future visits for people of this type are matters for the Minister for Foreign Affairs in conjunction with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I have no immediate details on those matters, but I am sure that Mr Hayden and Mr West will give details of them in another place. That is the extent to which I can answer the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Assuming that the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs will not, apparently, answer with regard to the codes of conduct, I will ask about the other part of my question which was not answered; that is, in regard to communication between, for example , politicians in this country and elsewhere. Is our democracy, in the Minister's view, so puny that it cannot resist or stand dialogue between us and politicians of South Africa? Surely that is how it will be looked at in the eyes of the world?

—I suppose it is a matter of judgment as to what Senator Missen considers to be dialogue. We have two South Africans, one a member of the ruling party in South Africa and the other a member of the President's Council of the South African Parliament, coming to Australia for what in fact are secret seminars. I believe that was not made clear before the decision was announced to the general public. That is clear now. I know that there are some members of the Opposition parties who are in fact extremely tolerant, if not supporters, of the policy of apartheid. However, I remind honourable senators that the previous Government, and in particular the previous Prime Minister, took an attitude on this subject as firm as that of the present Government. I find it strange that some honourable senators apparently have changed their views in opposition.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology to the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratories tabled on Friday. This inquiry was initially appointed by the previous Government and arose out of a decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the razor gang. I want to raise concern about the effect of Commonwealth employment in Tasmania if the report were to be implemented. The Armed Forces Food Science Establishment at Scottsdale and the Australian Government Analytical Laboratory and the Commonwealth Department of Health Pathology Laboratory at Hobart are said to be under threat with centralisation to the major cities the alternative. Will the Minister assure me that when the Government looks at the report full consideration will be given to the whole question of Commonwealth employment in the regions and the smaller States and that it is not necesarily the most efficient answer to centralise all Commonwealth activities in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne?

—I am advised by my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, that a Government response to the report has not yet been formulated. An inter-departmental committee composed of all relevant departments will be set up to consider the report. I would expect that in that time too particular matters of concern raised by Senator Coates in his question will be adequately considered. After these matters are given full consideration the Government response will be made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the Attorney-General the answer he gave Senator Chaney on Friday when Senator Chaney asked whether he had arranged for tabling of the Age tapes and tapes transcripts. The Attorney, inter alia, replied that Parliament's responsibility in relation to conduct of the judiciary begins and ends with the Parliament's role in relation to section 72 of the Constitution relating to misbehaviour and incapacity. Apparently the Attorney's view is that that is circumscribed in a very narrow way, as is the view of the Solicitor- General given in the opinion. Does the Attorney-General agree that a reading of the Constitutional Convention debates shows the overwhelming majority of the founding fathers of the Australian Constitution were of the view that Parliament and Parliament alone should have the final say on the question of judicial misbehaviour? In particular, I draw the Attorney's attention to a view of the then Mr Isaacs, the Attorney-General of Victoria, who said on 31 January 1898:

QUESTION.PARA: You must not allow the solemn verdict of the two Houses of Parliament on this question to be challenged elsewhere--

There were numerous other opinions to that effect by those who took part in the debate. How can the Attorney-General, in the light of all this and the Solicitor -General's own reference to the Convention debates in his opinion-although he did not mention these-justify his refusal to provide the factual material contained in the Age tapes and transcripts on which Parliament can decide, as it alone has the responsibility, the question of judicial conduct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I readily agree that the determination of whether something is a matter of misbehaviour in relation to section 72 of the Constitution is something for Parliament and not the courts and that the Convention debates were very careful to draw this distinction and in particular to insist upon an approach to this question which is very different from that which applies in Britain, the mother of parliaments, where the ground rules that are capable of being applied by the Parliament are very much more wide-ranging so far as the judiciary is concerned than the ground rules that have been thought appropriate in the Federal, written constitutional system here in Australia. Certainly I have no quarrel with the references to the flavour of those parliamentary debates that Senator Durack has made. However, if he reads the debates exhaustively and appreciates the context in which the arguments were being put and, moreover, if he focuses on the particular language employed in 72 (ii) of the Constitution, which talks not of misbehaviour at large but of proved misbehaviour, he will, I think, appreciate the force of the option of the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, that Parliament is not at large, it is not at liberty, to apply any criterion that occurs to it as appropriate in order to determine what misbehaviour might mean. A lot of learning has gone into that conclusion. It is not simply a matter of some intuition by the Solicitor-General ; it is a very carefully argued out conclusion, which I suggest follows quite inexorably from the materials to which he refers and from the whole course of Australian jurisprudence on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that Parliament is and should be circumscribed as to the matters that it can take into account. What Dr Griffith's opinion makes perfectly clear- this is consistent with what Mr Temby had said, rather more briskly, before him- is that there are only two sorts of circumstances in which it is appropriate for Parliament to pray for removal for misbehaviour. One is when there is some misbehaviour properly described as attaching to the performance of the judge in his judicial office. That is clearly not in issue in the circumstances of this case. The other criterion that is applicable is whether or not there is misbehaviour in the sense of criminal misconduct, some offence, not necessarily one that has been dealt with by the courts but one that might be dealt with by the courts, which is of such a character that it is obviously quite inappropriate for a judge to stay in office. They are the only two circumstances and situations to which it is proper for this Parliament to have regard.

When those two situations have been quite explicitly ruled out in the way that has been the case with Mr Temby's opinion, looking both at the law and the facts , and the Solicitor-General's opinion, I simply do not regard it as appropriate to go down the exploratory route that the Opposition is inviting me to follow. To do so is simply to give aid and comfort to those who would reduce the standard and tone of political debate in this country, and it does no credit to those who are seeking to follow that course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen the announcement by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Neville Wran, of the proposed establishment of a Judicial Commissioner of Public Complaints, who will have power to refer complaints to the National Crimes Authority for investigation? Does the Attorney-General agree that this is a welcome development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has noticed the announcement by Mr Wran yesterday of the establishment of a Judicial Commissioner of Public Complaints. The Commonwealth Government welcomes that announcement by Mr Wran. It further welcomes his statement yesterday that the New South Wales Government will support to the hilt the Federal Government's National Crime Authority.
—It is a toothless tiger; that is why he will support it.

—It further welcomes the announcement made yesterday that one of the roles of the Judicial Commissioner for Public Complaints will be to integrate the work of the Commissioner in New South Wales, so far as questions of official corruption are concerned, with the work of the National Crime Authority. Part of his function will be to make recommendations to the Government of the day which in turn will be translated through as references to the National Crime Authority. I suggest to someone such as Senator Chipp, who is minded to interject on the supposed weakness of this chain, that the point is obviously that when one has an independent judicial figure making a recommendation which is required to be formally tabled in the Parliament in the way that is the case here, it would take a very brave government indeed, and one much less sensitive than the Wran Government in these matters, to refuse to make the reference in question. The political weight would be entirely in that direction.

ANSWER.PARA: Might I say that the Commonwealth Government particularly welcomes Mr Wran's announcement in this respect, coming as it does, after a very long series of other initiatives in the fight against organised crime and corruption in that State. I think it is appropriate on an occasion like this to put this initiative in its context, lest some sordid and cynical minds opposite be inclined to think that this is some Johnny-come-lately idea which is not, in fact, part of a long and carefully developed strategy, honestly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I really think that the Attorney-General should not put propositions to the Senate which he himself does not take seriously, and obviously he does not take this seriously.
—There is no point of order.

—The proposal for the establishment of a Judicial Commissioner of Public Complaints is part of a long strategy, honestly and competently pursued by the Wran Government with fierce integrity over recent years. I refer the Senate to some passages in Mr Wran's speech yesterday which make perfectly clear for the record just what that record has been. Mr Wran said :

ANSWER.PARA: For the truth is that no government in Australia's history-
with the possible exception, of course, of this Government-
Federal or State, has done more, or as much, to fight crime and corruption and to enhance the standards of integrity in public office.

Look at the list: the declaration of pecuniary interests, the declaration of political donations, and the public funding of elections, the Police Board, the complaints against the police procedures, the Police Ombudsman, the strengthening of the police force, the closure of illegal casinos, the clamping down on S.P. bookmaking, new laws on prostitution, the Woodward Royal Commission , the Stewart Royal Commission, the Street Royal Commission and the Cross Special Commission.
We established the Office of the Crown Advocate to provide an independent director of public prosecutions.
We established an independent judicial tribunal to determine citizen complaints against the police.
We enhanced the powers of the Ombudsman to scrutinise and investigate complaints against the police.

He goes on to put the new initiative-the establishment of the special judicial commissioner of Public Complaints-squarely in the context of that record. It is in that context that the Commonwealth Government unashamedly and wholeheartedly expresses its support for this new initiative by the Wran Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy a question. In the light of the Prime Minister's embargo on uranium exports to France in force until October this year when a shipment of 250 tonnes of uranium is due to go to France, I ask: Is the Minister aware that the French nuclear power industry uses nuclear waste from so-called peaceful reactors for its nuclear bomb program? Is the Minister aware that France has not signed the Treaty on the Non- Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and transfers nuclear materials and technology needed for nuclear bombs to nations such as South Africa, Iraq-which this morning was accused of using chemical warfare-and South Korea? Is the Minister aware that the French Government has firmly restated its intention to continue nuclear testing in the South Pacific? Given that these acts considerably worsen nuclear proliferation and that the only acceptable solution is for France to end nuclear testing in the South Pacific, which it says it will not do, will the Minister take this opportunity to state unequivocally that unless France ceases nuclear testing in the South Pacific for good, Australia will permanently ban uranium exports to France?

—Senator Chipp listed about half a dozen items which I would regard as being anti-social or even irresponsible, and which he said were practices that the French were currently following. He asked me whether I could confirm this. I cannot confirm whether France follows all those practices. I cannot remember that off the top of my head but I can confirm a number of the points that Senator Chipp raised, the most important of which, I suppose, concerns nuclear testing in the South Pacific. France does follow those practices. For that reason, of course, and principally because of its testing in the South Pacific the Prime Minister and the Government decided last year that the shipment of uranium due to go to France in July 1983 would be postponed and that no shipments would be made, at least until October 1984. Since that date there has been a further Goverment decision to set up the Slatyer inquiry which is due to report at the end of May. Following receipt of that report, it is anticipated that the decisions will be made regarding the supply or non-supply of uranium to France in the period after October 1984. But until that report has been received and considered by the Government, I think it would be premature of me to make any commitments which seek to bind the Government because the Government has decided to defer those final decisions until the Slatyer report has been received.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: What steps has the Government taken to respond to a request from the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Mr Somare, for assistance in the event of a volcanic eruption in Rabaul?

—The latest briefing I have on this matter is dated 29 February so there may well have been some further developments, in which case I will report them to the Senate at an appropriate stage. The Australian Government is already responding, and responding vigorously, to the request that has been received from the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea for emergency assistance at Rabaul. The Government has been in touch with Papua New Guinea for some time and has arranged for a speedy and co-ordinated Australian response. The Prime Minister, Mr Somare, has been informed of our willingness to help. Australia will provide an emergency broadcasting system. The Government will help with temporary accommodation for those people not already provided for under the local evacuation plan. We are providing the services of two Australian experts in this respect. The former head of plans and operations of the Australian Natural Disasters Organisation, who is currently advising the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, is in Papua New Guinea to advise on the operations to date and on requirements. A Bureau of Mineral Resources officer has also arrived there to help establish a vulcanological information service. I have been informed that Papua New Guinea is accelerating work to upgrade a further airfield, and we shall be kept informed of progress in that respect. Detailed requirements for water supply construction are being worked out. The Government is monitoring the situation closely to ensure that we are ready and equipped to respond to any further requests from Papua New Guinea as the situation evolves.

—Has the Attorney-General prepared his own written option as distinct from those of Mr Temby and the Solicitor-General as to whether the judge referred to in the Age tapes is guilty of misbehaviour? If so, when will the Senate be given the benefit of his reasoning? If not, why did he, the Commonwealth's first law officer, decide that it was not necessary to formulate his own opinion?

—I am a little puzzled by Senator Rae's question. It is not normal to prepare one's own opinion for the sheer hell of it if one is wholly in agreement with the opinion prepared for one by one's senior law officers, in particular the second law officer of the nation, the Solicitor-General. I am fully satisfied that the opinion received from him, supported as it is by detailed reasoning, which was not the case on paper anyway so far as Mr Temby's early opinion is concerned, accurately reflects the law and, to the extent that it is appropriate, practice in this respect. I have indicated my support for both the reasoning and the conclusions of that opinion. I guess I will have another opportunity to do so in winding up the further debate on the tapes which will occur later today. I will have the benefit then, of course, of having heard Senator Missen's discourse on the relevant and applicable law, and it may be that I will be moved from my present position of so far quite unshaken commitment to the validity of the opinion that I received from the Solicitor- General.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Attorney-General to tell us upon what basis he formed the opinion that he did not have to form an independent opinion but could accept the one from the Solicitor-General without doing any research of his own.

—I am quite satisfied, following discussions with the Solicitor-General and also, I might add, earlier minutes from my departmental officers, that all relevant material was in fact scrutinised and perused by the Solicitor-General. I have, of course, read a number of slabs of that primary material, both in terms of the Quick and Garran type accounts and the Todd accounts, in the commentary literature, plus such case law as is applicable in the circumstances. I have not done my own primary research in the sense of going back through Halsbury and whatever else the Library may have on offer in this respect, but I repeat that I am completely confident that my departmental officers, Mr Temby and the Solicitor-General, have between them plumbed the necessary material, and I am completely satisfied with the reasoning that is deployed by Dr Griffith. In those circumstances, I do not propose to waste everyone's time, including my own, in retracking that kind of territory. I think if honourable senators asked Senator Durack they would find that it was only on very rare occasions that he deployed any further and better opinion writing expertise of his own in circumstances such as these.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: REFERRALS TO SPECIALISTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It follows Senator Bolkus's question of 28 February regarding the extent to which private medical specialists have benefited financially from referrals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I share the Minister's alarm at the figures that he provided to the Senate and I ask him whether he can explain why they should be so high.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that, in answer to a question by Senator Bolkus last week, I indicated that there had been an 18 per cent increase over the last financial year in diagnostic specialist fees paid by my Department and that this was out of character, particularly in New South Wales, because further examination shows that, of the $32m spent in this area of my budget last financial year, $17m was spent in New South Wales. Pro rata, it does not bear comparison, because it indicates a ratio that is completely out of character and unacceptable from the point of view of government spending. The instructions that my Department has given to local medical officers over the years are that in referring pathology, radiology and other such matters to specialists they should have regard to a priority system of sending them, firstly, to the repatriation general hospitals, then to the Commonwealth Health Laboratories or to the State or public hospital authorities and only in the last resort should such matters be referred to private specialists. It is clear that that arrangement is being breached.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been suggested to me that there is a very nice, cosy arrangement between some general practitioners and some specialists that allows this overservicing and certainly over-use of a system that has grown up because of the geographical changes in Sydney. Looking at the figures, I find it difficult to appreciate why , for example, one particular doctor in the Strathfield area got $110,000 for pathology. One could argue that, in the first instance, those matters should have been referred to the repatriation general hospital within that region. Once can only conclude that there has grown up a system which is being used by the specialists to the degree that it is out of character with the rest of the systems that are operating in all other States of Australia. I have this matter under close consideration with a view to introducing a system to curtail the obvious rip-off that has been perpetrated by some specialists and some general practitioners at the expense of the public sector and the taxpayer.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the report of claims last week by the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry that the national economy is in no state to cope with any form of tax cut and that tax cuts for workers would cripple economic recovery? What prospects does the Government see for personal income tax cuts next financial year by way of reductions in tax rates or indexation of tax brackets for inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have looked at the report in the Adelaide Advertiser to which Senator Maguire referred. I assume that Mr Nettle from the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has been accurately reported. All my comments will be predicated on that assumption. That being so, my summary, I suppose, of Mr Nettle's opinions is that they are simplistic in that they argue that if taxes are cut the deficit will increase or at least be higher than it would otherwise have been, and therefore inflation and interest rates will go up. That sort of simplistic economic dogma is reminiscent of that which was followed for six months of the seven years of the discredited former Government, which asserted the dogma that, if the deficit is reduced, inflation will automatically fall and interest rates will go down and vice versa. For most of the time that the discredited former Government was asserting that dogma the empirical evidence was running in the opposite direction. It continues to do so.
—That is hardly true of France, is it?

—This year, for example, in spite of the strenuous cost of saving or rigorous expenditure controls applied by the present responsible Government, a deficit of the order of $8.5 billion-an increase of almost 100 per cent on the deficit which had applied in the previous year-was still inevitable. In spite of that, the inflation trend is unarguably downwards. It has fallen quite considerably already and the same thing has happened to interest rates. In other words, the views attributed to Mr Nettle are difficult to reconcile with the empirical evidence-not necessarily from all of the world, Senator Rae, but from a greater part of it.

ANSWER.PARA: What Mr Nettle has overlooked, as I think the previous Government overlooked, is the influence of cost push inflation-something recognised by the Australian Labor Party for many years and preached by the Labor Party for many years to the discredited former Government-and flowing from that, the necessity for a consensus about prices and income, which was finally achieved by the present Government in its final stages in opposition just before the Federal election one year ago, in the form of the prices and incomes accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is the accord, and not the size of the deficit or any other economic variable per se, which is crucial. Incorporated in the accord , among other things, was an expectation that tax relief would be provided, especially for low and middle income earners. That expectation was refered to quite recently by the Prime Minister. In a radio interview on 4 March he said:

. . . let me say this that in the area of tax, we weren't able in the area of tax reduction, to do it in our first budget. We will I believe be able to have tax reductions in our second budget and we aim to do that in the context of a reduced deficit and in doing that we will obviously seek to give relatively greater relief to those who need it most.

Very similar comments were made by the Treasurer at a Press conference on 26 January. Insofar as the taxation position is a part of the accord, it is something to which, as the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have both already said, the Government will turn its attention. I might add-this is perhaps equally important-that included also in the accord is a commitment by the Government to take positive action against tax evasion. Indeed, of course, those two things are related. The scope for tax reductions is influenced by, amongst other things, the degree to which the Government is successful in forcing tax evaders to disgorge that which they should have paid long ago to the Commissioner of Taxation. Flowing from that, of course, it follows that the more sections of the Senate use their numbers to protect tax evaders, as they did last year, the less scope there will be for cutting taxes for those honest taxpayers to whom the Government believes an obligation exists under the accord and in accordance with Australian Labor Party policy in general.

—My question is also to the Attorney-General. I am sorry that he said he does not intend to assist the Opposition any further in answering questions about the tapes. I trust he will be able to give me some information on what I am asking now. I refer him to the answer he gave to Senator Durack on Thursday of last week about the apparent failure of Mr Ian Temby, QC, in his opinion on judicial behaviour to refer to some of the matters discussed between the judge and the solicitor and which have been published in the Age newspaper and elsewhere. —Order! The question has been asked.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Moreover, Mr President, they were asked very nicely, and I acknowledge that. I do not know whether it is the case that there were five transcripts unavailable to Mr Temby. That is the first I have heard of that and I certainly do not believe that to be the case. The full bundle of material that was supplied to me by the Age was, in fact, physically taken over personally by the Acting Crown Solicitor and delivered to Mr Temby. Up until now I have been under the complete belief that all those conversations were involved. ANSWER.PARA: As to the question as to whether or not Mr Temby had regard to all the conversations, that is, the conversations allegedly involving the judge directly or allegedly referring to the judge, it is my clear understanding that Mr Temby did have regard to all that material. Although he may not have given any detailed analysis of every one of the conversations or every one of the subject areas in question, there is no doubt in my mind, having talked to him, that he did have regard to every reference in the material to the judge and, as such, I am completely confident that the conclusions he reached about the absence of any pointing of the material to criminal misconduct or the absence of any material pointing to judicial misbehaviour in any other relevant sense represented a firm conclusion based on a proper scrutiny.

I do find it regrettable that to some extent in this question, and more particularly in the previous question that was asked of me, there seems to be a mounting disposition in the Opposition to now turn its sneering and smearing tactics on Mr Temby and to treat him in exactly the same way as Mr Sinclair-in admittedly more robust fashion-sneered and smeared at Mr Justice Cross last week . There is a fine tradition in this country, which I would hate to see undermined, of respect for the judiciary and, moreover, respect for those whose professional independence, competence and integrity ought to be absolutely beyond doubt. It was on that basis that Mr Temby was appointed Director of Public Prosecutions without any adverse reaction or comment from the Opposition at the time. Indeed, I was privately congratulated by a number of members of the Opposition on the good sense and attractiveness of that particular choice. It was on the basis of the competence, integrity and honesty of Mr Temby, combined, of course, with the fact of his impending assumption of the role of full time Director of Public Prosecutions, that he was briefed on this sensitive and difficult matter to advise the Government as to whether or not there were grounds for believing that there may have been misbehaviour. To challenge Mr Temby's bona fides or to challenge Mr Temby's diligence in the way that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has just done is, I believe, to behave in a way which is unworthy of honourable senators in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Attorney- General: On what was his clear understanding based-which he mentioned in his answer-in regard to this matter?

—I said it was based on conversations with Mr Temby and conversations also, I add, with the Acting Crown-Solicitor, who was there and was available to consult with Mr Temby at all relevant times and who, I know, was fully aware of all of the material, such as it was, in the transcripts that purported to relate to the judge. It was also evident from the text of Mr Temby' s opinion which, although focusing in detail on two or three particular areas, employed language which was general in character and its conclusions and, as such, was quite enough to satisfy me.

Given the Federal Government's commitment to upgrade occupational health and safety by implementing a national strategy in close co-operation with all States and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, could the Minister suggest what steps the Federal Government could initiate to ensure that such issues are fully assessed to consider adequately the occupational safety implications of such a decision?

—Senator Reynolds gave me brief notification of the question and I have received some advice from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. First, let me say that I am not aware of what the Queensland Government is planning in this regard, although I understand there have been newspaper reports of it. We instituted the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Health and Safety for that purpose. It was set up to examine problems of the kind which Senator Reynolds has raised. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERATED CLERKS UNION: TAXATION OFFICERS BRANCH

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise with the Leader of the Government in the Senate the current dispute between the taxation officers branch of the Federated Clerks Union and the Public Service Board. The dispute relates to the position of members of that union who contract repetition strain injuries due to keyboard work during their initial period of probation in the Australian Taxation Office. Is the Minister aware that if at the end of the probation period the injuries to the employee are so serious that he or she cannot perform keyboard work, that person's appointment to the Public Service is annulled or, to put it in plain terms, that person is sacked? Is the Minister aware that people in these cases, unlike permanent Commonwealth employees, do not receive compensation for their work related injuries, nor are they offered any alternative employment? Can the Minister inform the House of what action, if any, the Government has taken in this dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter raised by Senator Richardson has been raised with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Public Service Board by the Federated Clerks Union. The Government views the situation with considerable concern and the Public Service Board has been asked to conduct an inquiry into the matter. When the results of that inquiry are available they will be reported to the Government and any appropriate action will be taken.

ANSWER.PARA: One or two other important matters were raised by Senator Richardson in his question. The situation which Senator Richardson described in his question has been occurring. The Government has directed that, pending the outcome of the review by the Public Service Board, there be no further annulments, as they are called, of probationary employees suffering from repetitive strain injuries. Secondly, I thought it was implicit in Senator Richardson's question that probationers suffering from repetitive strain injury incurred in the course of their employment in the Public Service were not eligible for compensation. My understanding is that that is not correct and that all employees, whether they be probationers or not, are eligible for compensation and that there are claims pending in respect of probationers who have incurred repetitive strain injury. I understand that there can be no immediate solution to this question, but all steps have been taken, I understand, by the Public Service Board to ensure that there is no proliferation, as it were, of the injustice while the matter is being investigated by it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of concern in the community generally and in the National Association of Community-based Children' s Services in particular regarding fee relief for low income users of children's services? In particular, is he aware of concern that the present guidelines on fee relief as required by the Office of Child Care may well create serious financial problems for some centres and disadvantage many low and middle income users of those centres? Can the Minister assure the community that moneys promised in the last Budget will be used to establish new services and upgrade existing ones and not be used simply to finance modifications of the fee relief system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of concern amongst some children's services organisations in this country of the impact of the new fee relief proposals-the special economic needs proposals particularly-in the funding of children's services. As a result of that concern we have had one consultation in Canberra and meetings with various groups throughout the country. Out of that have arisen new proposals which I am in the process of considering at the moment. The problem with providing fee relief in subsidised child care centres is considerable. In the past we have run into difficulties throughout the country in that the concentration of children's services has not necessarily been in the areas of most need-certainly not in low income areas. We have had the problem that some of the fee relief procedures used by some children's services have not , in my view and that of the Government, been aimed at giving maximum relief to low income earners but rather at giving relief in an unbalanced way so that in some cases high income people have received considerably more relief than was necessary. As a result of this we are in the process of finalising our new proposals for a new and revamped fee relief service which will go before the Government in, I hope, the next couple of months.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Haines also asked about moneys provided in the Budget. First of all we have provided moneys for many new services. I am sure Senator Haines would know this. New services are being developed throughout the country and new types of services are being developed with greater concentration on multi-purpose centres and those services which provide not only the traditional child care but also long day care, respite care and sometimes assistance for 24 hours a day. Such centres will remain open for 24 hours a day in special circumstances. Clearly, if we are going to expand the special economic needs area, which some people would desire, within the limited child care budget that would mean that some of the expenditure would go into the economic needs area at the expense of new services. That is a matter which is constantly under consideration. We are concentrating on using new money for new services and developing an economic needs subsidy service which better spreads the burden throughout the whole range of incomes in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, refers to criticisms that have been made of and recent Press coverage that has been given to the storage of the national map collection by the National Library of Australia. Is the Minister aware of allegations that inadequate storage is leading to the deterioration of an extremely valuable map collection and that the cramped conditions of storage of the maps means that worthwhile work and research is impossible? Is the Government undertaking any investigation of the National Library's handling of these maps? Does the Government consider this a matter of urgency?

—My colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has investigated this matter and has provided me with some information, which I will now give to the Senate. I am advised that the space for the map collection is cramped but, as I am sure Senator Martin will be aware, so it is for almost all of the Library's activities. Remedial measures are being taken to correct a roof leak which has developed in recent months. I am advised that no significant damage has occurred to the map collection. The Library's acute space problem, which has long been a principal cause of management difficulties, was exacerbated by the decision of the previous Government in 1981 to deter the construction of this much needed extension.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In response to a question from Senator Reynolds on 1 March in relation to the release of contaminated water from the Mary Kathleen uranium mine site I indicated that the release was accidental and had occurred while liquid was being siphoned to a lower pond to avoid possible overflow from an upper pond during extraordinarily heavy rain. That advice was based on a briefing earlier provided to me by my Department which in turn was based on information supplied from the Queensland department. I table a document prepared by Mr McGregor, First Assistant Secretary in the Uranium and General Division of the Department of Resources and Energy, which is his note for file on that question. My Department has now drawn to my attention that it was misinformed on the nature of the incident. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a background information statement dated 27 February 1984 by Mary Kathleen Uranium Ltd.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
BACKGROUND INFORMATION STATEMENT (27.2.84)
Release of Evaporation Pond Liquid at Mary Kathleen

Since the commencement of operations at Mary Kathleen in 1958 the process liquids have been retained and evaporated in large ponds. When operations ceased late in 1982, work started on a 2 to 3 year programme aimed at drying out the ponds, cleaning up the area and revegetating it.
Operation of the evaporation ponds at this stage in the programme involves the pumping of liquid between ponds to maintain optimum evaporation conditions over the area.
There are two main evaporation ponds and several very small subsidiary ponds.

Prior to the commencement of the monsoonal rainfall, the larger main pond was almost empty in preparation for the next phase of the rehabilitation programme. The other main pond was only 70 per cent full.

Rain began on the afternoon of Monday February 13th and continued until Friday 17th February. A total of 242mm (approx. 10 inches) fell during this period. In anticipation of larger rainwater flows, extra freeboard was created in all of the ponds by transferring liquid into the larger main pond. However, rainwater filled the particular subsidiary pond faster than anticipated, because the liquid level had not been adequately adjusted.
In order to prevent pond liquid from overflowing approximately 1 megalitre of liquid was released in a controlled manner, by syphoning it into Cameron Creek.
The release was stopped immediately the level of liquid in the pond was stabilised.

The liquid in the evaporation ponds is over 90 percent water, with less than 10 percent of solids in solution or suspension. The bulk of these solids are manganese and iron salts. Other elements or salts contained in small proportions include:
Calcium
Sodium
Sulphate
Uranium
Thorium
Aluminium

The salt content and radioactivity level of the liquid put it above drinking water levels. The liquid is acidic and most of the dissolved salts in the liquid only remain in solution at relatively high levels of acidity. When the acidity of the liquid is lowered (such as when the liquid is added to ordinary water with a more normal PH level) various salts precipitate out. This happened when the discharged liquid met the creek water. The dissolved salts therefore precipitated into the creek. These, together with material in suspension caused staining of the creek and left a residue on the creek bed.

It should be noted that, although the quality of the liquid in the pond was below potable standards, it was considerably diluted when it entered the creek. Extensive tests are being conducted to determine the exact composition of the creek water and the solids deposited on sections of the creek.
For information: Terry Ward, General Manager-MKU Telephone (077) 43 8311 A/ Hours (077) 43 2988.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement indicates that the controlled release of contaminated liquid into Cameron Creek took place. Neither I nor my Department was aware of this at the time I answered Senator Reynolds's question. I had been briefed on the basis of advice to my Department from a senior official of the Queensland Government that the release was accidental. Unfortunately that advice was incorrect. I add that I intend to take follow-up action, firstly, to determine the level of impurities in the water still in the pond in question, and, secondly, to determine what measures can be taken to ensure that there is no recurrence of this incident. I note again, as I noted when answering the question on 1 March, that those are matters which will have to be taken up with the Government of Queensland because it is responsible for the rehabilitation of the Mary Kathleen uranium mine site and not the Commonwealth Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMMITTEE ON DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT AND OCCUPATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report gives us some very interesting facts about the operations of the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation. The areas of discrimination at which the Committee looks, together with State committees, cover a very wide number of matters-sex, colour, ethnic origin, marital status and all sorts of things. In view of the debate we had in this place last year on the Sex Discrimination Bill, I wish briefly to bring to the Senate's attention some quite fascinating figures that appear in the report. Debate on the subject of sex discrimination tends to centre very much on discrimination against women, probably understandably so since many women would claim that most of the discrimination in Australia is against women, but also it has been made a more emotive debate by virtue of the campaign that was run against the ratification of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. So the debate has been essentially in terms of discrimination against women, but this report brings out some important facts which might broaden a little the interest in the subject of discrimination.

The report points out, for example, the increasing trend of complaints from men . It says that this is probably one of the most significant trends in the subject of discrimination and complaints about discrimination that the Committee can identify. For example, the report says that there was a 14 per cent increase in the number of complaints made by men in the year 1982-83 and that complaints of discrimination on the ground of sex by men increased by 47 per cent, which is a very remarkable increase. The Committee comments in the report that the significant increase in complaints from men is largely due to complaints of discrimination in non-traditional occupational categories. I should have liked a little more information about that.

I am conscious, for example, that one sees more male nurses these days in training as general nurses. I am conscious that men are being employed as stewards by airlines, a position that used to be referred to as 'hostess' but now is dignified with the title 'airline attendant' or 'flight attendant' since it refers to both men and women. I am delighted to see that. However, as those are two apparent areas where discrimination against men is breaking down, I should have been interested to know what the other significant areas are, and I think that the community would have been interested to know. It is possible that in the future perhaps the Minister who represents the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in the Senate, Senator Button, will enlighten us on the matter. As I said earlier, the report makes the following statement: Overall, the potentially most significant emerging trend is the relative increase in complaints from men, particularly on the ground of 'sex'.

I think for many reasons it is a very interesting report. I am sure that other honourable senators will want to say a few words about it while they have the opportunity today. I just point out that I think the understanding of the problem of discrimination on the ground of sex has been rather one-sided, and it is salutary at this point of the Parliament's debate on the subject that it be pointed out that this Bill and other measures to overcome discrimination on the ground of sex are good for men as well as women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to say a few words on the report of the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation. I suppose it is rather telling that Senator Martin and Senator Giles have spoken and now I am speaking to this report. But perhaps that is what we are here for; to do some different telling. I am particularly interested in the contents of this report, not the least because the first task of members of the incoming Committee was to reappraise what had gone before prior to setting new goals or emphases for themselves in their forthcoming term of office. They felt that it was very important to do that before they sailed ahead. In particular, they undertook an analysis of what had gone before to see whether that had been fully effective in dealing with the complaints and, in particular, to see whether the methodology of dealing with complaints was satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Giles has already referred to the fact that the Committee came up with a couple of new emphases to which it wanted to devote this triennium. In particular, the Committee wanted to look at the question of whether the groups most likely to be discriminated against were aware of the Committee's complaint handling role. It is well and good to have procedures to deal with discrimination but if no one knows about them, in particular those people who are discriminated against, they are to no advantage at all. The Committee also wanted to examine how long it took to deal with complaints. Again, as Senator Giles has said, it wanted to place particular emphasis on the equal employment opportunity personnel practices to be promoted to employers, employees and unions. The Committee also wanted to examine the conciliatory approach and how that worked in dealing with complaints. Another thing that seemed important to the Committee was the concern for groups that were disadvantaged as apart from individuals. The Committee has placed an emphasis on community involvement and, in particular, information passing to the community so that it can inform those groups in the community that are likely to be discriminated against.

Other honourable senators have mentioned the change in complaints that have been brought before the Committee. I think it is interesting to go through those again in a little more detail. Up until 1973, the majority of complaints were on the grounds of sex and they were submitted by women. They were mainly related to employment practices and policies, in particular, those things that referred to barriers to recruitment and training; positions that were open only to men or only to women. There was a denial of equal opportunity for both sexes to equal advancement. There were differential systems of conditions for men and women. There were requirements for women to resign in certain conditions. There were reduced benefits for women under superannuation schemes and a compulsory earlier retirement age for women. Interestingly enough they are not the sorts of complaints that continue to come before the Committee, partly because some of those complaints have been appreciated as being matters that need a change of regulation or legislation. So those conditions, at least in some areas of employment, no longer exist.

However, complaints on the grounds of sex still constitute some 65 per cent of the complaints, but the nature of the complaints is now somewhat different. They include: Discriminatory advertising and recruitment practices; differing criteria for employee benefits, such as low interest loans; employment of women in the defence forces, which is a problem that has been alluded to under the sex discrimination legislation; and the problem of sexual harassment. The point that Senator Martin raised is stressed and can be stressed again by me: There is a significant increase in the number of complaints from men on the grounds of discrimination due to sex mainly referring to non-traditional areas of male employment.

There have also been some other areas of complaint apart from the area of sex discrimination. There have been some complaints on the grounds of race, national extraction and also, curiously enough, discrimination on the grounds of age. Not only are people who are old complaining about the problem that confronts them in terms of continuing employment or retirement but also there have been an increasing number of complaints from young people who complain that they have been denied access to apprenticeships because of the maximum age limit. Other reasons for complaint are listed. As Senator Giles said, there are very few case histories so we cannot elaborate on the interesting things in this report which do bear examination. I congratulate the Committee on preparing a report that has analysed past procedures, compared them with the present, and put down some proposals for how it will deal with these matters in the next triennium.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH AUSTRALIAN LOCAL GOVERNMENT GRANTS COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

The 1983 annual report of the South Australian Local Government Grants Commission reports on the Commission's activities in 1982-83 and on the recommended grants to local governments in South Australia for the current financial year. The South Australian Local Government Grants Commission allocates funds to local councils which have been passed on to South Australia from the Commonwealth Budget. A total of 30 per cent of the funds are allocated to local councils on a population basis, with equal amounts per head of population, and the remaining 70 per cent of the funds are allocated to councils on a needs basis, on the basis of certain formulae that determine efforts made by councils in expending and raising moneys.

Since 1974-75 funds have been made available from the Commonwealth Budget to local government. The Whitlam Government established the precedent, giving the first ever grants from the Commonwealth Budget to local government in Australia. Something of the order of $450m annually is now paid from the Commonwealth Budget to local government throughout Australia. This year councils in South Australia will receive some 8.6 per cent of the national allocation from the Budget, totalling some $39.5m. Funds paid in my own State go not only to local councils but also to such important bodies as the Outback Areas, Community Development Trust which services those parts of South Australia without local government, and the Coober Pedy Progress and Miners' Association. Currently local government grants are based on a formula which provides that 2 per cent of personal income tax collections from the Commonwealth Budget are paid to local government. In that way, the funds paid to local governments are different from funds paid to the States. In the case of the latter, funds are based on the total tax collections rather than specific personal income tax collections.

Last financial year local councils nationally received a 21 per cent growth in funds from the Commonwealth Budget, but this year the rate of increase will be far lower, and I think it is very important to outline the reasons for that very low increase. One reason is the effect of the wages pause introduced by the former Government. The very slow growth in income tax and the consequent slow growth in funds to local authorities is one of the side effects of the wages pause which was not thought through very clearly by the former Government. As a result, there has been a very big impact on local government in Australia. Certain income tax cuts were also made late in 1982. Over and above that was the effect of the economic recession in compressing incomes and, therefore, taxation collections. This financial year the growth in funds to local councils from the Commonwealth Budget will be of the order of 8.2 per cent.

Concern has been expressed by a number of local authorities about their real growth this financial year. Their concern is that the allocation of funds from the Budget should keep pace with inflation. Certainly, the Budget provides for a growth of 7.5 per cent in the consumer price index this financial year, which gives some apparent real growth, but I acknowledge that the consumer price index is more a measure of costs faced by consumers than costs faced by organisations such as local authorities. However, there is some encouraging news that the gross domestic product deflator, which is a more broadly based measure of inflation, was running below the 7 per cent rate late last year, and that suggests a real growth in funds for local government this financial year.

The Government is concerned by the slow growth in funds to local government. I am pleased that the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) late last year indicated that there would be an inquiry into local government finances during 1984. I welcome the announcement by the Minister. I welcome his expression of concern for local government finances, and I am pleased that the Minister will announce soon the membership and terms of reference of the inquiry into local government finances. I hope that one of the aspects looked at will be the case put by South Australia for a bigger share of funds.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

This Parliament has a special obligation to make sure that some of the ill-founded discussion which goes on in the community and which is aimed at raising an image of many of the veterans as, in Australian terminology, bludgers must be put down strongly and vigorously wherever it occurs. That type of talk, which is seemingly becoming more rife and which could be used by a government as an excuse for inactivity and lessening of effort in this area, would have untold consequences within the community. At a stage when we are looking at a review in this area I merely urge that we do not wait until 1988 to meet the more obvious needs and that this review concentrate on those areas of priority that are not so blatantly obvious to anybody who goes into the repatriation hospitals.
