SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was adjourned last Tuesday afternoon I had commenced to put down the Opposition's views on the statement which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) had just presented to the Senate on this major issue of what has become known as the Age tapes and transcripts. In the few minutes I spoke at that stage of the debate I outlined the principal concerns which the Opposition had in relation to the statement. I highlighted the question of the authenticity of the material, the question of the judge's conduct and also the general question of Parliament's role in dealing with the misbehaviour of judges. There are a number of other issues which I dealt with then and before that, which I have dealt with since and about which I have outlined the Opposition's concern. I think those matters will be the subject of continuing debate. Indeed, many of them have been brought out in the course of questioning by the Opposition of the Attorney-General over the last few days of sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I come back particularly to that part of the statement dealing with the conversation the judge had with the solicitor and the matters which are apparently revealed in the tapes and transcripts concerning the conversation. The Attorney-General has taken an extremely restrictive view of Parliament's role in this matter. As questioning has proceeded of the Attorney-General on this matter he seems to have become even more restrictive in his attitude to it. I said last week that the Opposition does not accept the restricted view of misbehaviour which was the opinion of, presumably, Mr Temby, certainly of the Solicitor-General, and has now been adopted by the Attorney-General although we have not been given any written opinion by him. He has gone out of his way to emphasise on several occasions that he adopts the opinion of the Solicitor- General and Mr Temby on this matter.

We are now faced with a situation in which the Government, in handling the matter of the tapes and transcripts, has excluded completely any further consideration of or attention to the role of the judge which may be-or may not be for all we in this Parliament know-revealed by these tapes. It is a fact that the Parliament has not been fully informed about the role of the judge as revealed in the tapes and, as yet, it has not been informed as to views on the authenticity of the material even though the Attorney-General decided, on the basis of the material that he was given, that he would discuss the matter of the tapes and even though there has been some recognition-I use that as a neutral word-by the judge in those conversations with the Attorney-General that there may have been some discussions of the kind referred to in the transcripts by him with the solicitor.

There are on foot a number of major issues concerning the role of the judge, quite apart from the other issues raised by these tapes. Although the Opposition has expressed concern about them and they will be in future the subject of further discussion, I do not propose to deal with those other aspects this afternoon. I will concentrate on the positon of the judge and the role of Parliament in regard to it. As I have said, the Attorney-General has taken a very restrictive view of the role of Parliament in regard to judicial conduct. He made it perfectly clear, in answer to questions from Senator Chaney last Friday and from me today, that he regards Parliament's role as beginning and ending with the constitutional provision that a judge can be removed only for proved misbehaviour or incapacity on an address of both Houses of Parliament praying for his removal. It is on that subject that I wish to concentrate now.

The Attorney-General has adopted the position that Parliament should take his view, enlivened as it may be by an opinion of Mr Temby, who is the Director of Public Prosecutions designate and who, whatever his legal qualifications may be in the criminal sphere or any other sphere, is not, I think, presented by the Attorney-General as an expert on constitutional law. It is also enlivened by an opinion of the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, who of course, recognised as an authority on constitutional law. Nevertheless, the Attorney-General takes the view that this is purely a matter for him in his role as a member of the Executive. He is to be advised on the material presumably by Mr Temby and on the law by Dr Griffith. The Opposition does not accept that position at all. In the course of this debate, as in debates concerning the Australian Constitutional Convention there will be a good deal of support for this and aspects of what I call the constitutional law argument, which I have not time to deal with this afternoon.

Suffice it to say that the Attorney-General, in answer to a question from me today, has recognised that the decision on this matter is a decision for the Parliament itself, the Parliament alone. It is not for the High Court of Australia to interpret or to review.

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliament acting in accordance with law.

—If Senator Evans does not agree with that he can tell us so later. That is certainly the view of the Opposition. It is the view of the founding fathers of the Constitution. We believe very firmly that that view should be adhered to. It would be an absolute travesty of our democratic Constitution if, on a subject of this kind, the address of both Houses of Parliament would not determine the issue, and determine it once and for all. I quote from one of the contributors to a debate on this matter, no less a person than Sir George Turner of Victoria. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Now, can we imagine a deliberative body like the Parliament of the Commonwealth removing one of the Judges of the Federal Court unless on the strongest possible grounds, and for the best possible reasons, and after having given everybody the fullest opportunity of being hard on every point in question?

Surely that is a clear affirmation of the role and responsibility of Parliament; an affirmation that the decision should be left to Parliament. That is the case that the Opposition is making today. The Attorney-General has challenged that fundamental principle and continues to challenge it and to defy the role of Parliament in this matter, both on principle and in his answers to questions-in which he has made it clear that he will not provide Parliament with any further information. He will not even provide Parliament with the material on which Parliament itself can make a judgment, given even the restricted view of Parliament's powers maintained by the Attorney-General. According to the Attorney-General, we are not to be provided even with the material on which we can make that judgment. Because the many opportunities that have been given to the Attorney-General over the last week to provide adequate information to the Parliament have not been taken up, we believe that the time has come when we must make some move to ensure the role of Parliament. Therefore, I move:
At end of motion, add:

'and that there be laid upon the Table of the Senate without delay all those portions of the transcripts and transcripts of any tapes not so far transcribed which refer to any conversation between the judge and the solicitor or other conversations referring to the judge or in which he participated, together with the aide-memoire of the Attorney-General's discussions with the judge on February 15 and 24, subject to the deletion from all documents of any name or identifying characteristics of individuals'.

In moving the motion in those terms, I am indebted to no less a person than the Attorney-General. I recall very well that in September 1982 in the teeth of the Costigan debate the Attorney moved a motion for the tabling of papers by my colleague, the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, and me. During that debate on 8 September, when moving the motion, he said:

It is only by access to these documents that it will be possible now, given the attitude that the Government has taken, for an objective view to be reached as to where the merits and the truth lie. If the Government has anything to hide, I can understand its continued reluctance to make these documents available.
There were many debates on this issue at the time. On 14 October in one such debate Senator Evans said that the Senate was trying to have the papers tabled:

. . . in order to determine for itself whether the Executive arm has been discharging its constitutional responsibility to enforce and maintain the laws . . . Even if we accept, as I do not, that the Parliament here is somehow seeking to exercise itself an Executive function, it really is just claiming too much for the constitutional doctrine of the separation of powers as that doctrine is developed in Australia, to say that this in itself constitutes an absolute barrier to the Senate taking the action in question . . .

which, he then said, the Executive was resisting. At that time there was a real argument as to what the Executive responsibility was in regard to certain of those papers, which were opinions, police reports and so on and which were clearly within the Executive's responsibility. But Senator Evans brushed all that aside, saying that those papers must be tabled so that Parliament could see whether the Executive was doing its job. That would perhaps be a good argument in this case as well, that is, to see whether Senator Evans, as Attorney-General , is doing the job for which he is responsible. But in this case, the question of the removal of judges is not the Executive's responsibility. Nor indeed, is the censuring of judges. It is the responsibility of Parliament to pass a view on the conduct of judges. The Parliament may not decide, in its wisdom, that that conduct provides grounds for the removal of judges. That is not the Executive's responsibility. It is the Parliament's responsibility, which Senator Evans has today at long last recognised, although apparently he now wants to make some qualifications to that. It is Parliament's responsibility.

In this motion we are saying that Parliament must be given the material on which it can make that judgment. It has to have the material. If the Government will not make the material properly available to Parliament, Parliament must see to it that it gets it. It will then, of course, have to consider how to handle it. Clearly, questions have to be considered by Parliament regarding the authenticity and the full text and context of the discussions. We do not know the full context of those discussions. We cannot rely on Mr Temby's opinion. Mr Temby was asked, as far as I can see, to give an opinion on whether the judge had committed any criminal offence. He was also asked to give consideration to whether any material could warrant the conclusion that was reached concerning the ground of proven misbehaviour. As I have already pointed out, Mr Temby in his opinion has not dealt with certain of the matters which have already been published in the Age concerning the transcripts. For all we know there may be other material which bears upon the judge's conduct.

Mr Temby's opinion is quite deficient in dealing with all the matters in question. I notice that this has been pointed out in an article which appeared during the weekend in the National Times. On Senator Evans's own admission, there were something like 10 conversations. But Mr Temby's opinion deals only with three or four of them. So we cannot be expected to rely on Mr Temby's analysis of them. For goodness sake, he did not have time to analyse them properly. He was given less than two days to analyse 524 pages of transcript. How would he have had time to research the law on the constitutional matters which were raised as well? This is an absurd proposition from the Attorney- General. The fact is that, even if Mr Temby had put down the most detailed and most perfect opinion on all these subjects, it is the Parliament's right to have the material, to consider the material, and to make the final judgment on that material.

I conclude with one or two remarks upon the standards of judicial behaviour which are called for in this country, which are expected by the people of this country, and which the judiciary of this country has an enviable record of meeting. Sir Winston Churchill, in speaking in 1954 in the House of Commons about the standard of conduct of the judiciary, said:

A form of life and conduct far more severe and restricted than that of ordinary people is required from judges and, though unwritten, has been most strictly observed. They are at once privileged and restricted. They have to present a continuous aspect of dignity and conduct.

That quotation from Sir Winston Churchill is contained in a major book on the conduct and standards of judges, how they are removed and so on, published in 1967 by Mr Shetreet and called Judges on Trial. It is the up to date and standard work on the subject of judicial conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Britain, you silly character. It is totally different in Australia. There is a fundamental difference.

—Well, we have already shown how wrong the Attorney-General is on that. It is no good because it is a British text book! What about the book on the British Constitution by Mr Todd, a nineteenth century book, quoted by the Solicitor-General? What a remarkable outburst from the Attorney-General-it is no good because it is British! But the Solicitor-General relies on a nineteenth century British text book. At least this is an up to date and late twentieth century text book.
—You clown. You absolute intellectual clown. If you cannot appreciate that difference, you ought not to be on your feet in this place.

—No, it does not make any difference. The role of the Parliament in this matter is supreme. As Sir George Turner said, the Parliament, of course, would not act capriciously. The Constitution certainly makes the signal clear to the Parliament that it is to act only on grounds of proved misbehaviour or incapacity, but ultimately the Parliament is the body which decides these matters. It decides what are the standards by which misbehaviour is judged. It decides what are the standards by which incapacity is judged. It decides those issues not only as a matter of fact but also as the ultimate court in relation to these matters. This is the old tradition of the High Court of Parliament. Over the last week not only has the Attorney-General shown that his record as Attorney-General on civil liberties is very much at risk and at stake, but also his whole attitude to this matter reveals that his understanding of the democratic rights and the ultimate responsibility of Parliament is just as deficient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Durack has said and what the Opposition has to say on this matter. I do not propose in this speech to go into a number of other matters which are relevant to the argument on the tapes, but I think the matters raised by Senator Durack in his statement on 28 February and the questions he thought appropriate to be asked in the Parliament, which have been asked and expanded on since that time, are highly relevant; and I agree entirely with him. I understand that earlier today the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) thought he might be moved by my argument, which of course will be criticism of the opinions on which he relies. I am not so optimistic as to expect that. I hope to move the people of Australia to a realisation of what this means, but I would be too optimistic altogether if I expected to move the Attorney-General entirely from the fixed position in which he has already set himself. When I say 'fixed position' I should say his 'present fixed position', because if one takes the--
—He will change tomorrow.

—If one examines the questioning of last week one finds that the Attorney-General started by giving us some selective answers-I refer here mainly to the matters which the judge has said and I will be concentrating very much in that area-and then said that he thought they meant this and that his discussions with the judge were so and so, although we have not heard the lot. By Wednesday it had all turned hypothetical. We learnt then that the judge was not acknowledging that he had had any such conversations, but, if he had, they would have gone something like this and this might be so. This was greeted by humour in this chamber and it was a very weak situation. The Attorney-General resiled from that position, and so we come to Friday's position and today's position, where in effect he has said: 'There is no need for me to answer you people. There is no need for me to give any more information about this. We are satisfied. The Government is satisfied. You should be satisfied. You have no right to interfere further and ask further questions. I am not going to investigate the matter in connection with the judge any further and have not given the Special Prosecutor any such instructions'. Given that rather varied opposition and attitude of the Attorney-General, we can understand the remark of Mike Walsh just before Christmas that Senator Evans is to politics what Inspector Clousseau is to crime control. I do not know what next week will hold.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with the Attorney-General's statement before I turn mainly to Dr Gavan Griffith's comments and views. Several things in the Attorney-General's statement, I think, call for independent mention, because he put it down as an authoritative view. He referred, of course, to the remarks Mr Temby had made- that very early opinion he gave-on the meaning of misbehaviour when he told us that it was very limited, that Parliament must observe it, and that was that. One might say that that view was somewhat injudicious. For some reason better known to himself, he defined 'injudiciousness' in his later opinion, but I would have thought he was in grave difficulty in telling the Parliament what its conclusions were and in trying to place it in a straitjacket which it is not obliged to be in. Of course, it has an obligation to go much further when dealing with this matter.

One finds on page 13 of the statement put down by the Attorney-General that he mentions the joint statement he made with the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) on 17 February. To summarise the statement, he said that the conversations between the judge and the solicitor, even if authentic, could not support any conclusion that the judge had been guilty of criminal misconduct- honourable senators will realise that that is the way it has been defined by Mr Temby; it has to be criminal misconduct-nor in the opinion of Mr Temby could their contents, if authentic, support in any way a conclusion that there had been misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Australian Constitution. So that conclusion and Mr Temby's opinion was that misbehaviour has a very fixed meaning and that the Parliament is bound to accept it. The Attorney-General went on to say in that statement:

Both the police report and Mr Temby's opinion make it clear that there is no basis upon which any further police or Special Prosecutor investigation of the alleged behaviour of the Judge, as revealed by the tapes and transcripts, could be justified.

That is, apart from the fact that he has been to see the judge and has assured us that many of his statements are in a rather different context than would be evident at first sight. I have already expressed my view of the folly of the course he adopted of seeing the judge; and I hope that that folly has come to his attention in the last few days. The thing is that this shuts out the Parliament and suggests that the Parliament is not entitled or indeed obliged to examine serious allegations which are made about the behaviour of a judge. Senator Evans further says in the statement:
I am satisfied, and the Government is satisfied, that there is no basis at all on which any substantive motion based on misbehaviour could or should be moved.

That may be his opinion. It may be the Government's opinion. But it is the only conclusion to which the Senate can come when it sees the documents and the material, when it has the reports that are being undertaken at present, and when , with regard to this particular series of allegations, the Attorney-General does not intend to pursue, through the Special Prosecutor, any further examination.

Reference has been made this afternoon to Mr Todd, a writer well before the Constitutional Convention, a man who expressed views in England. That apparently has now been deprecated by the Attorney-General, yet in his opinion, at page 16, he places great reliance on Mr Todd.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the date of Mr Todd's work on this?

—I am not sure. It was sometime in the nineteenth century, certainly a long time before the constitutional conventions at the end of last century. On page 16 the Attorney-General was then quoting with approval Mr Todd' s work. Honourable senators should listen to this. The reference is:

SPEECH.PARA: Misbehaviour includes-
note that 'includes'-

firstly, the improper exercise of judicial functions; secondly, wilful neglect of duty, or non-attendance; and thirdly, a conviction for any infamous offence, by which, although it be not connected with the duties of his office, the offender is rendered unfit to exercise any office or public franchise.

Of course, there are differences in the provisions in England as opposed to those here, but it is important to realise-and this will be found in other things referred to here, which the Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General totally ignore-that the wording includes 'misbehaviour'. It includes these things. It is not exclusive. It is not suggesting for one moment that there are not important other matters in judicial behaviour, matters such as improper associations with people, scandalous behaviour, interference in political affairs, and denigration of public officials. One could go on in a number of other areas about things that do not constitute a criminal offence but constitute the sort of action which would bring down a judge's good name, which would no longer allow him to be respected in the community, and which would bring down the judiciary generally in disrespect. It is my contention that those are the sorts of areas that must be considered by this House and the Parliament in its entirety.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under section 72? Is that what you are saying?
—Yes.
—You have completely misread the law.
—I am not going to let you, Senator, interrupt my speech. You put down a statement and opinions, and I am replying to them today. I shall not be deflected from my task by any interruptions.

SPEECH.PARA: When referring to these matters, as to what are the duties of the Parliament in this respect, the Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General refer to a number of authorities, to Quick and Garran and others, and I think that they take them right out of context. But let me refer to something to which the Attorney- General has not referred-expressions by Lumb and Ryan, authors of The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia Annotated, a recognised authority. In that work they say this about section 72, which has not been interpreted by the courts and is a matter still of some speculation. This is what they say on page 234 about the method of removal of judges:

The removal procedure by address from the Houses of Parliament is the usual form of removal provided for in the Constitution Acts of the States and has been followed on the federal level. The question arises as to whether the High Court, if a removal of a judge were challenged before it, would require that a certain burden of proof be satisfied before the judge could be removed, or whether the requirement of proof is a matter which is within the sole jurisdiction of the Houses of Parliament and the Governor-General in Council; in other words, whether the only requirement is that the behaviour must clearly be proved to the satisfaction of the Houses of Parliament and the Governor-General in Council. It is more likely that this latter interpretation would be adopted, and that, apart from the case of a clearly politically motivated removal where there was no evidence of misbehaviour or incapacity, the High Court would not interfere with a proposed removal which has complied with the procedure laid down in s 72.
That is the kernel of my case so far as this is concerned, and it is not the case of the Solicitor-General or the Attorney-General. I maintain that that is a sound judgment of the law.

I turn to certain matters in the opinion of the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith. He was asked questions. He was asked the question about the meaning of misbehaviour in section 72 and in particular whether misbehaviour for this purpose is limited to matters pertaining to the judicial office in question and conviction for a serious offence which renders the person concerned unfit to exercise the office. Except for the fact that he does not say that conviction is necessary, he gives the Attorney very much the answer that he wanted because, at the end of a very tortured opinion, on page 14 at paragraph 23, he answers the question:
Misbehaviour is limited in meaning in section 72 of the Constitution to matters pertaining to-
(1) judicial office, including non-attendance, neglect of or refusal to perform duties-

I interrupt there to say that that seems to be a very narrow meaning of judicial office; I think that there are many other things that might be done in a judicial office which in themselves would be matters which Parliament should consider. He goes on:
(2) the commission of an offence against the general law of such a quality as to indicate that the incumbent is unfit to exercise the office.

I reject the idea that that is the limitation, that it is limited in that way, and I intend to go on to show that. The position that follows in this opinion is that Dr Griffith, on page 3, makes some reliance there upon Mr Todd's work, which has already been referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in 1887.

—Yes. In regard to this work, whereas in the Constitutional Convention the whole section was referred to, in paragraph 5 of the Solicitor- General's opinion, he quotes the definition, including the word 'includes', but there was no attention to that. He then also points out that there are latter parts in that statement, that is, that the power given to parliament is that of the exercise of that superintendence over the proceedings of the courts of justice, which is one of their most important functions, a right to appeal to the Crown for the removal of a judge who has, in their opinion, proved himself unfit for the proper exercise of his judicial office. This power is not in a strict sense judicial. It may be invoked upon occasions when the misbehaviour complained of would not constitute a legal breach of the conditions on which the office is held.

SPEECH.PARA: He says further that, in entering upon an investigation of this kind, parliament is limited by:
no restraints except such as may be self-imposed.

Of course, the Constitutional Convention imposed this restraint that parliament should consider matters of proved misbehaviour and incapacity, but it was for parliament to have its attention drawn to them and for parliament to constrain itself with reference to them. It is curious that later on in the opinion, Dr Griffith loses his interest in Mr Todd and prefers the opinions of the text writers here in Australia instead; Quick and Garran he then finds rather convincing.

It is very interesting that in regard to his opinion, Dr Griffith draws attention to what were the intentions of the founding fathers who met in the conventions at Adelaide, and there is reference to their general discussions, where they quoted Todd and various other writers. But he seems to have ignored entirely the significance of the Constitutional Convention debates in Melbourne that followed in the following year. It was there, of course, that the actual terms of section 72 were brought together; they were changed and they reached their final form. The significance of things said at that time, in that Conventon, by leading politicians of the day is important. One has been referred to by Senator Durack today-Sir George Turner. I shall not refer to what was said by him, but I shall refer to statements by a number of others. In the opinion that we have here, Dr Griffith points out that the judges do not regard it as necessary to consider the extent to which debates may be regarded. A number of the judges-Gibbs Chief Justice, Mason, and Wilson-have accepted Chief Justice Griffith's dictum, that it is permissible to have regard to Convention debates for the purpose of seeing what is the evil to be remedied. Then Dr Griffith goes on in a summary of what was the conclusion which I challenge. He says:

Perusal of the Adelaide and Melbourne Convention Debates confirms the extent to which the delegates desired to deal with the need adequately to safeguard the independence of the judiciary as an essential feature of the separation of powers in the Federal system.
He refers to Todd's summary read by Mr Isaacs as the perceived meaning of misbehaviour. He then says:

Each of the successive amendments to the draft clause was intended further to limit, for the purpose of the Constitution, the power of removal to a single specific and narrow basis related solely to the established ground of removal for breach of conditions for good behaviour.
That is a most unfair, most incorrect interpretation of the debate, particularly when it was finalised in Adelaide. He says:

The general discretionary power of Parliament to address for removal on grounds other than misbehaviour, in the technical sense understood by the delegates, was eliminated, with the function of finding such misbehaviour vested in the Parliament rather than in the Executive.

That is true, but it is a quite unfair down-playing of the debate. Parliament, and certainly not the courts, was to make the decision. While the clause was limited to misbehaviour and incapacity or proved misbehaviour and incapacity, it was for the parliament and not the courts to determine a serious question like that. Let me read from the remarks which Mr Isaacs made in that debate. He said:

You must not allow the solemn verdict of two Houses of Parliament on this question to be challenged anywhere. If you do, what will be the result? To carry the case I have supposed one step further, the Judge is removed, or is attempted to be removed by a vote of the two Houses. We must always suppose that any Judge would have the fullest and fairest opportunity of defending himself before the two Houses. If the one House does not give him that opportunity I cannot but suppose that the other will.
So it was expected that that was what would be done. Mr Kingston, the then Premier of South Australia, said:
How do you propose to prevent it being challenged?
After some discussion, Mr Reid said:

If you add to the words 'praying for such removal,' the words 'upon the ground of misbehaviour or incapacity,' I think you would get rid of the difficulty. Make it necessary that the addresses shall allege misbehaviour or incapacity.
It must be alleged. It must be drawn to the Houses' attention. That, of course, means that they would have a view on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word 'proved' is missing from that.
—I will get to that, do not worry. The word 'proved' was not in the wording then; it came in later, for a good reason. Mr Kingston went on a little later to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We are all agreed that it is desirable to protect the Judges so long as they behave themselves in the best sense of the term, but at the same time on this question of good behaviour or misbehaviour we should make the position of the Federal Parliament unchallengeable and without appeal.
That, of course, is what the founding fathers endeavoured to do, and, as I have said, succeeded in doing. Mr Barton, Australia's first Prime Minister, had this to say in the debate:
We cannot conceive such a thing happening, for the safety of, and with benefit to the Commonwealth, as that a Judge, having committed some misdeed-
I ask honourable senators to note the word 'misdeed'-

or having lost his capacity, should find himself so utterly opposed to the decision of Parliament upon the matter that he should turn round and appeal to his brother Judges for a decision in his favour. We ought not to put him or the Federal Court in that position, and I do not think that it would conserve the dignity of the Court if we were to impose such a task upon it.

Surely that was not done. Surely it was not the intention of the founding fathers, nor what they did. Sir George Turner has been referred to. His remarks were very much along the same lines. He referred to reckless behaviour. Things like this are not necessarily breaches of the law, but the behaviour of judges may have to be investigated by the parliament, in its duty. Mr Symon said:

The only point is whether the final decision of the question should be left to the body described in the clause, namely, the Senate and the House of Representatives, followed by the Governor-General in Council. I entirely agree that they ought to be the complete and final judges of the matter. It would be impossible and absurd that there should be an appeal to the tribunal of which the accused Judge-if I may use the expression-was a member; because he would continue to be nominally a member of the bench until his formal removal from it.
The result of that was that the grounds were then worded in the present form. The Convention then considered the following amendment to the motion:
. . . 'upon the grounds of proved misbehaviour or incapacity' be added to the sub-section.
Why was that? Mr Kingston said:
We want to make it perfectly clear that the decision of the Houses as regards the matter of fact shall be conclusive.
So it was suggested that the amendment could read either in that way or as follows:
. . . upon the grounds of misbehaviour or incapacity, proved to the satisfaction of such Houses.
Mr Reid said that that was not necessary and that he did not think that even the word 'proved' was necessary. Mr Issacs finished the debate by saying:

I understand that the Drafting Committee will not be bound by the form of words adopted by us now, and that if the amendment is carried they will frame the clause using such language as they think will meet our intention, and ensuring that the addresses shall not be passed except because of what Parliament believes to be misbehaviour or incapacity, and that the finding of the two Houses shall be unchallengeable.

Mr Symon said 'Hear, hear', and the amendment was agreed to. That was the finish of the debate. Anyone could read what the Solicitor-General said about the purport of the Convention debate. It is clear that it was the intention of the founding fathers to ensure that parliament would be unchallengeable if it considered or was directed to consider any proved misbehaviour or incapacity. In addition, the Solicitor-General acknowledged in his statement that Parliament has the right to prescribe any procedures which might be necessary. At paragraph 15 he said:
Obviously 'proved misbehaviour' is to be established to the Parliament, and whatever the offence, such proof is not predicated upon anterior conviction in a court of law.

I think that is quite right. He went on, however, to deal with another very interesting matter. This is where he came to the conclusion of his opinion. He referred in paragraph 20 of his opinion to the following question:
whether the offence is of such a nature as to render the person unfit to exercise the office, although it is not committed in connection with the office.
He said:
The notion that private behaviour may affect performance of official duty was expressed by Burbury C. J. in Henry v. Ryan . . .
These are the words that I quoted the other day:

. . . misconduct in his private life by a person discharging public or professional duties may be destructive of his authority and influence and thus unfit to him to continue in his office or profession.

He did not seem to bother to go on with that line. He left it, whereas I think it is a significant factor. It may well be the way in which a judge's whole authority is destroyed and why he, because of his conduct, may in certain circumstances have to be removed. He relied then upon Sir Garfield Barwick's opinion. He followed straight on with a view expressed by Sir Garfield Barwick, in an opinion to the Government on the Reserve Bank Bill of 1957. The conclusion is put this way:
Thus the 'misbehaviour' in the Bill-
the Reserve Bank Bill-

. . . will be held to refer to conduct touching and concerning the duties of the member in relation to the office, but will also include acts in breach of the general law of such a quality as to indicate that the member is unfit for office .
He used the word 'include', not 'exclude'. He referred not to the total package but to what is included. He immediately followed by saying:
I concur with this opinion. It represents a contemporary statement . . .
He said:
. . . the terms of section 72 dicates meaning for 'proved misbehaviour'.

He came to the conclusion that it was not that it included this or that, but that it was limited in meaning to the two things that he chose to be the way in which parliament must deal with it. I say that the opinion is faulty and a misuse of such authorities. Of course we do not have any authoritative determination by the courts of meanings of these things. But I think a couple of other rather useful things can be brought to the Senate's attention in making up its mind as to its own authority. I refer to the ruling by the first President of the Senate, Sir Richard Baker, in 1906, which is referred to in Odgers' Fifth Edition of Australian Senate Practice. Ruling 347 reads:
There is no authority outside the Senate competent to decide whether the proceedings have been regular or irregular.

The learned author, in his writings, refers to Cormack v. Cope, indicating that if the Parliament in its carrying out of legislation does not go through the required constitutional proceedings, the legislation may well be found to be constitutionally invalid. He refers also to the case of Browne v. Cowley and a statement by Chief Justice Griffith, before he was Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, when he said:

I think that in dealing with this point the court ought to bear in mind the rule as laid down by Blackstone, and quoted by Sir James Stephen, in the case Bradlaugh v. Gossett . . . 'The whole of the law and custom of Parliament has originated from this one maxim-that whatever matter arises concerning either House of Parliament ought to be examined, discussed, and adjudged in that House to which it relates, and not elsewhere'.

That, I think, is a general statement, a general authority. Of course, it may be read down in some circumstances but it should not be in this case. This is a matter for Parliament to make its decision.

I refer finally to the whole question of justiciability, which the Solicitor- General does not bother about, and the fact that many parts of the Constitution which prescribe duties to the Parliament will not be interfered with by the courts. Professor Ryan, the learned author of a paper to the Australian Constitutional Convention about putting constitutional conventions into a legislative form, referred to section 47 of the Constitution and stated:
. . . questions of disputed elections are to be determined by the House in which the question arises.
There are other provisions of this sort. He stated further:

However, it can be said while the Courts are under a duty to determine the validity of any attempted excercise of legislative power and to exercise the judicial power with which they are vested under the Constitution, the exercise of the reserve powers of the Crown does not in itself give rise to justiciable issues; and it would be quite possible to detail in the Constitution the rules . . .

This whole question of whether a thing is justiciable, whether a court will interfere, is a matter that is not resolved in this section of the Constitution; but I suggest that, because of the intention of the founders of the Constitution , it would not be one that would. I would have liked to refer to the case of Osbourne and the Commonwealth in which some reference was made to this matter but time does not allow that.

Finally, I have come to some conclusions from the authorities before us. One could also ask, in the words that were made rather famous by Mr Ian Sinclair last week: 'How could they have got it so wrong?' How could the Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General have got it so wrong? They have wrongly sought to restrict the power of parliament. They have told us, quickly and in advance: ' You are not entitled to make a proper inquiry'. Parliament does not just have a power but it has a duty, where allegations are made, to investigate those allegations and to be satisfied from its own knowledge, not from the filtered processes which the Attorney-General chooses. It is the duty of the parliament in doing these things-there is a necessity for us all to exercise natural justice-to have these things proved to the satisfaction of the parliament.

Aside from actions which have no semblance of misbehaviour, where the parliament acted in a purely political way, the courts will not interfere with a serious determination of facts made by the parliament. The Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General of this country can advise the parliament; in fact they should. But they have gone further than this. They have attempted to circumscribe the Parliament and to tell it what it should do. It is our job to act with caution because of the nature of these tapes. It is our job to act in the interests of preserving the integrity of the judiciary. This is a job which is facing this Parliament; it is not one that can be taken away from it. For these reasons, I support the amendment and I suggest that the views which have been expressed in law by these learned gentlemen are unsound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in the Senate chamber this afternoon embarking on what I would take to be a very grave matter because it could involve questions relating to the exercising of a quite extraordinary power vested in the Governor-General in Council upon an address being framed and made by the Houses of the Parliament in a way which could lead to a member of the Federal judiciary being removed from office. Therefore, I think it behoves this chamber to take the matter with the seriousness which I believe has been the occasion up to now. I agree with Senator Durack and Senator Missen that the question of the interpretation of section 72 of the Constitution, which is the fundamental section with which we are concerned, is not justiciable. It is a matter for the Parliament. To that extent I entirely agree that anything that is done within either House of the Parliament in relation to section 72 is not something which can be the subject of judicial review. There is no question that what goes on within the walls of this Parliament in relation to the exercising of the powers conferred by section 72 is a matter for parliamentarians in the exercising of a very extraordinary public duty and obligation cast upon them by that section.

SPEECH.PARA: I entirely agree that this is not a justiciable matter; it is a matter which we have to resolve and determine for ourselves. What we do is unchallenge- able and without appeal. Therefore it makes us even more conscious, I suggest, of the heavy responsibility placed upon us. It is quite apparent, to put it in its most obvious form, why this is so. One could not have a judge in this situation, according to Senator Missen, appealing to a bench of fellow judges to second guess the parliament in relation to his proved misbehaviour or incapacity. There are deeper reasons having to do with the separation of powers why it is so that this matter is not justiciable. Having said that it cannot be a matter of review by the courts, it is not surprising, therefore, that we have no judicial assistance or precedents to guide us in our deliberations as to the true role of the parliament. We have to turn to the texts of learned authors to note the law and custom of parliament. I will come to that in a moment.

I also want to make clear what is the role of the Parliament. Let us remember that it is not to remove the judge. The role of the Parliament is to frame and make an address praying or alleging that certain misbehaviour or incapacity is the case. Honourable senators should not forget that it is the Governor-General in Council who has the power and responsibility perhaps to remove the judge. It is the Governor-General in Council-it is specifically put in those terms in the Constitution-advised by his Ministers who exercises the power of removal. He awaits the address of both Houses of Parliament before he can act with his Executive Council. That is where the actual power resides. He awaits our action before that power can be exercised.

What action is required? What is it that the Parliament has to do in relation to section 72? I think it is quite legitimate to turn to such learned authors as Arthur Horatio Todd, who I believe wrote his text in 1894. Therefore, it was available and present in the minds of the framers of our Constitution. I never call them founding fathers. The framers of our Constitution would have had before them quite clearly the benefit of Todd's review of the law and customs of parliament. In my remarks in this chamber last Wednesday I said, and I still think it is probably correct:

I take the view that the opinions put forward by Mr Temby and the Solicitor- General as to the sort of criteria which are proper for the explication of that constitutional provision which states that on the address of both Houses the Governor-General may remove a judge for proved misbehaviour embody the tradition and succinctly state the correct criteria which ought to be applied by this chamber if it has such a matter before it. Certainly, we should be extremely cautious or wary of applying a more general standard of misbehaviour than that which is indicated by the tradition, namely, that there must be some misbehaviour in relation to the discharge of the duties of office or some proved offence which is of such a heinous or grievous nature as to render it quite improper for such a person to continue in such high judicial office.

I believe that this nineteenth century text is relevant because, as I say, it clearly would have been present in the minds of the framers of the Constitution as it was recorded and recounted by Quick and Garran, who were not only eminent lawyers but also participants in and contemporaries of the whole process of the framing of the Constitution. Therefore, what they say was the understanding of the framers of the Constitution, who had Todd before them, I think carries considerable weight. One must look at the opinion given by the Solicitor-General -I do not rely on Mr Temby at all-because, as Senator Durack said, it is the Solicitor-General who is an acknowledged expert in the field of constitutional law. Mr Temby has experience in other areas of the law. I believe he has practised in criminal jurisdiction amongst others. The position, as put by the Solicitor-General, Dr Griffith, in paragraph 5 has been conveniently summarised by Todd. He states:

Behaviour means behaviour in the grantee's official capacity. Misbehaviour includes, firstly, the improper exercise of judicial functions; secondly, wilful neglect of duty, or non-attendance; and, thirdly, a conviction for any infamous offence--

There are three matters that could possibly amount to misbehaviour: Firstly, improper exercise of judicial functions; secondly, wilful neglect of duty or non -attendance; and thirdly, a conviction for any infamous offence. Of course, whichever of those three matters is relevant would have to be proved in some appropriate way to the Senate chamber or House of Representatives chamber. That is quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they the only three?

—They are the only three that are relevant because of this point which is made constantly in the opinion. There is a reliance on the debates and, particularly, the understanding of Quick and Garran; namely, that whereas in England a judge could be removed for any of those three reasons of misbehaviour which amount to a breach of the conditions of holding the office, in addition there could be a more general address by the Westminster Parliament which could lead to the removal of a judge without having to show that any of those three conditions had occurred. The framers of the Australian Constitution decided not to vest that general power in the Australian Parliament to make an address praying for the removal of a judge on the basis of any other matters than those three matters which amount to breach of the conditions of the holding of the office. That is made quite clear by Quick and Garran in reliance on the debates.
—How can you conclude that that is an exhaustive definition of ' misbehaviour'?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not saying to the Senate-I think I tried to make this clear in my remarks last Wednesday-that that is, in fact, an exhaustive definition of misbehaviour. What I am saying is that when the Constitution was framed the framers of the Constitution had before them a very clear understanding of the tradition and the customs of the Westminster Parliament and they very deliberately made a decision to cut down, to curtail, to restrict what, in normal parlance and in normal thought, might constitute misbehaviour justifying removal from office.
—Has the British Parliament ever removed a judge from office for anything less than serious misbehaviour in a general sense?
—I cannot answer the question. I do not know enough of the individual instances.
—That is where Mr Shetreet would be helpful to the Attorney- General. He might learn more about it.

—I am making my own contribution. My contribution is that we are entitled to draw on the tradition, as known to the framers of the Constitution, at the time of the making of the Constitution at the end of the nineteenth century. They were quite clearly of the mind that a judge ought only to be removed for one of those three reasons which would have to be proved to the Parliament. Proof of those breaches of the conditions of the holding of the office is required. In relation to the third, namely, some sort of criminal offence, I am confident in saying that it was not intended that Parliament should, somehow, resolve itself into a court, exercise judicial power and assess whether certain facts had occurred and assess whether those facts amounted to a breach of the criminal law with some offence attracting some sort of penalty. Rather, as I see it, the role of the Parliament in all this is to receive proof in an appropriate way-by looking at the record of some court-that an offence did occur, and then it is the role of the Parliament to characterise, to give a certain colouring, to give a certain assessment of the weight of the grievousness of that particular proved offence. In other words, it is up to the Parliament to decide whether that particular conviction amounts to misbehaviour in the true sense of something that is infamous.
—And if no proceedings are brought?
—If there is no conviction the Parliament cannot proceed in this matter.
—That is not the case. The Crown can proceed on the basis of that which would found the criminal proceedings.
—I am giving my opinion.
—I don't know what the hell you base that on.

—I have not had the benefit of the full exposure. My point is that the role of the Parliament is to characterise the offence which has either attracted a conviction or, I am advised by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), which could possibly be brought to the court to attract a conviction. I have not had sufficient time to consider that. However, as I see it, the role of the Parliament is to characterise the offence as one amounting to misbehaviour; that is, infamous conduct even though the offence itself has nothing to do with the exercise of judicial function, nothing to do with incapacity to actually discharge the duties of office, nevertheless is so infamous as to call for, to cry out for, the removal of that judge from the high office which he holds. To that extent, the quotation from Chief Justice Burbury was correct, insofar as matters occurring in one section of a person's life can have a profound effect on his ability or propriety to hold office even though there is no absolute necessary connection between the two.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the case Senator Missen quoted was of a rather different order . A policeman had been found only in his underclothing in the grounds of St Mary 's College in Hobart, a school for Catholic girls. This was thought by the court to be conduct such as could amount to a breach of the disciplinary code of the police even though it had nothing to do with, say, insubordination or refusing to carry out an order given by a superior officer. It was, nevertheless, a breach of discipline or could be misconduct amounting to a breach of discipline in the view of the court. All that shows is that something occurring in one portion of a person's life may lead to a conclusion that it is quite improper for him to hold high judicial office. But under our Constitution we are not able to wander at large through a person's life and find out whether the holder of a federal judicial office has conducted himself or herself in such a way as to warrant the conclusion that the incumbent is unfit to hold office. We are restricted to the criteria put forward so succinctly by Todd that requires that there be a breach of the conditions of holding office, namely, some improper exercise of judicial function, a wilful neglect of duty or non-attendance, or a conviction for an infamous offence. That was before the framers of the Constitution and that explains why they restricted the matter, not to misbehaviour, but to proved misbehaviour relying on that particular line of authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the Solicitor-General's opinion.
—It is the Solicitor-General's opinion.
—No. He says no conviction is required.

—I believe the honourable senator has completely misunderstood the Solicitor-General's opinion. He does say that proved misbehaviour is to be established to the Parliament and, whatever the offence, such proof is not predicated upon anterior conviction in a court of law. I insist that we have to come to our own judgment as to what is right or wrong. We are not able to draw on any precedents available from the judiciary. My understanding of it would be that all that the Solicitor-General is indicating is that there are three criteria, three possible ways in which the holder of Federal judicial office may bring into being a situation where there can be an address for his removal. I have indicated them time and again. So it does not depend only on a prior conviction; it can depend, amongst other things, on improper exercise of judicial function, wilful neglect of duty, or non-attendance. Insofar as it relates to some general breach of the law, there has to be a conviction, and that is what I believe to be the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before this chamber can embark upon making an address for the removal of any holder of Federal judicial office, there must be brought before it proof, in whatever the appropriate way might be, of an improper exercise of judicial function, and I do not think that that has been alleged; proof of a wilful neglect of duty or non-attendance, and I do not think that that has been alleged ; or proof of conviction for any infamous conduct, and that is not the case. It has been suggested by way of interjection that we are waiting on some prosecution to take place and that that is somehow putting the Parliament in a subordinate position to the decision of some prosecuting authority. Actually, I believe that that is the case. I believe that it was intended that that be the case. I believe it was intended that, rather than this chamber resolving itself into a court to determine whether any particular conduct amounted to a breach of criminal law, what we are required to do, in a judicial manner, a conviction for an offence having occurred, is to try to characterise the offence and decide whether it amounts to infamous behaviour. That would be our role. We are dependent, therefore, on the opinion of the prosecuting authorities as to whether a prosecution ought to be launched. In that regard, Mr Temby's opinion becomes relevant, and since it is in the public domain one is entitled to quote from it. Mr Temby, having read the transcripts and heard the tapes, states on page 2:
The first general point to be made is that the material I have seen could not of itself warrant the laying of charges against anybody.

He explains why, in the absence of any authentication of those tapes, it would be difficult, if not impossible, to make them the basis of any high criminal standard of proof in the absence of any admission. Throughout his opinion he states that the matters outlined in the tapes, even if taken to be authentic, do not amount to material such as could found a prosecution. For example, with regard to the question of the judge perhaps playing a role of persuasion in the appointment of a person to an office within the New South Wales Public Service, he stated:
If it be the case that (the Judge) used influence or persuasion, direct or indirect, to have him appointed to that position, then that carries no consequence so far as criminal conduct is concerned.

Such instances occur throughout the opinion. In other words, Mr Temby pointed out that as a prosecutor he would find it almost impossible to find in the material that has been handed to him admissible evidence and, even if it were in a state of admissibility, there is revealed in it nothing which would allow one to say that any criminal activity may have occurred which would warrant prosecution. So insofar as we await that conviction, we nevertheless have it from the Special Prosecutor that a prosecution is unlikely to be forthcoming.

I believe, therefore, that this chamber is left in a state, perhaps, of discontent, perhaps of having some misgivings, perhaps of being somewhat upset that it cannot engage in this wholly judicial function of deciding whether an offence of the requisite kind of seriousness has occurred. Its function is to decide, an offence having been proved before it by looking at the record of a court, whether the offence is of sufficient seriousness, is of a character which demands, cries out for, removal of a judge. We must await a conviction before we can decide that. As Dr Griffith, the Solicitor-General, stated in paragraph 21 of his opinion:
In matters not pertaining to office, the requirement-
and this is where I think Senator Missen has been misled-
is not conviction for offence in a court of law.
That is true, but that sentence cannot be taken in isolation. He continued:

In as much as Parliament considers the matter, the question is whether there is proved offence against the general law of ''such a nature as to warrant the conclusion that the incumbent is unfit to exercise the office'' . . . The Parliamentary enquiry is whether commission of an offence of the requisite quality and seriousness is proved.

I believe that that is the role of this chamber. When an offence is proved before us, by looking at the court record, we must then decide whether the requisite quality and seriousness amounting to infamous misconduct or misbehaviour has occurred. We cannot proceed until that is put before us.

I believe it is for this chamber to make up its mind finally. I believe it must have regard to the law and custom of Parliament, as indicated in the authorities that were available to the Australian Constitutional Convention, because we will find no other aid to the minds of the framers of the Constitution. I believe when one does that, one must come to the conclusion that the opinion by the Solicitor-General correctly and succinctly states the tradition and custom that the framers of the Constitution adopted for the conduct of matters of such high importance as this by this Parliament. For that reason, I support the Attorney- General to this point and repudiate the amendment put forward at the end of the motion by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —A year ago today I was elected to this Parliament, and I am very proud to be able to stand in this Parliament. I was even more proud to be elected to the Senate, where meaningful and responsible debate takes place and where, as a result of the Australian Democrats holding the balance of power, significant debate takes place because it is possible for legislation to be amended, improved, adopted or rejected on a non-partisan basis. A good illustration of that was the Sex Discrimination Bill. Today I believe we have dropped our standard. Let us put this debate into perspective from the Democrats' point of view. I do not think that anybody in Australia has a reputation which can match that of Senator Chipp in his campaign to fight organised crime in this country. The Australian Democrats have supported him and will continue to support him to the hilt in that fight against organised crime. We will join with any party, any body, any organisation or any part of society to fight against organised crime. We believe it should be a major concern of the parliaments, the courts, the police and the public of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, let us look at the issues with which we are confronted at the moment. Some questions need to be asked from both the pro and the anti points of view. I think a number of questions need to be asked in the context of this debate. Firstly, should police make public the evidence and the innuendo that they gather in their police activities? Secondly, should the fruits of illegal activities of the police, which produce evidence which is not acceptable in the court, be used to denigrate citizens who cannot defend themselves in the courts because no charges are laid? Thirdly, at a time when laws of libel are under scrutiny is it fair and just for newspapers to publish scandalous gossip gathered from purported transcripts of illegally obtained tapes which have yet to be tested for their genuineness? Fourthly, should the newspaper have printed these defamatory articles, minus the names, with an awareness of the potential for the names to be subsequently revealed either inside or outside this Parliament or any other parliament? Finally, why has the public denigration of David Combe in the Parliament-with some substantiation by tapes-been considered reprehensible by certain newspapers when the public denigration of other people in this way is considered justifiable by those same newspapers?

I believe it is absolutely vital for this country to have a free Press. I admire the free Press and particularly the newspapers which are the subject of complaints concerning the revelation of these matters. I believe that the Age and the National Times have behaved over the years in a very responsible manner. I applaud their willingness to research and to conduct in-depth investigations into matters that they believe are of public concern. I take nothing away from their desire and their willingness to get in there and find out what is at the bottom of these matters. I think nevertheless that those questions need to be asked of those newspapers and all newspapers in this affair. On the other hand, with the reputations of Australia's parliamentary system and judicial system impugned by the publication of the tapes transcripts why have not the Federal and New South Wales governments appointed a royal commission to investigate the manner in which the tapes were made, transcribed, distributed and used? Why was this matter not referred to Mr Costigan, for instance?

I think the questions which need to be asked in this context are: Firstly, were the tapes used to blackmail anybody? Secondly, were they doctored? Thirdly, did they lead to the need for top level crime investigations which were not followed through? Fourthly, who knew about the tapes' existence and when? Fifthly, if the tapes and the transcripts are authentic what further action should be taken, and by whom? Sixthly, were other tapes produced under similar circumstances which have not yet come to light-for whatever reason, including the selectivity of the person making the tapes and handling the tapes? Finally, on this side of the question, what measures, including legislative, need to be taken to protect the civil liberties of all Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why don't you answer those questions?

—I am not going to answer those questions because I have a very real concern for what is happening in this Parliament at this time. I am concerned with the abuse of parliamentarians' time in debates such as this. My speech will be very brief to emphasise that point. However, I needed to put the matter into context. The Australian Democrats abhor the abuse of the forum provided by the national Parliament to drag reputations through the mud in the way that has been done this year. If parliamentarians want to throw dirt then I ask them to throw it out in the public arena and not to abuse the forms of the Parliament to throw that dirt. I ask them to cease the abuse of the great privilege of freedom to say virtually anything on practically any subject-a magnificent freedom given to the parliamentarians of this country-and, I remind honourable senators, a privilege denied to all other Australians, even those who are the subjects of attacks in this Parliament. I ask parliamentarians to stop using the time and the privileges of this Parliament to conduct the lower form of political campaigning in here. I am appealing to all honourable senators, to all parliamentarians to get on with governing and legislating for the people we represent.

SPEECH.PARA: The hours that we have spent on debating these tapes I believe should have been used to debate subjects such as human rights legislation, which is still pending ; industrial democracy legislation, for which many people have been waiting for years; tax and sales tax injustices which are endemic to this country; ways of stopping nuclear proliferation-my God, people who have seen films such as The Day After or the magnificent film which I was privileged to see last night, Testament, must be concerned at the lack of concern shown by parliamentarians on this topic-or how we can rescue small businesses in this country from the dreadful state to which they have finally succumbed as a result of being neglected by the parliaments of this country. We should be debating the future of Australia's banking system-a red hot issue at the moment. We should not be taking up our time in the way that we have this afternoon with this debate. We should be debating Australia's education crisis and the escalation of health costs, Australia's pension and superannuation systems and our country's future defence direction. The National Crime Authority itself should be the subject we are debating today, not this mud that has been thrown around this Parliament for the last couple of weeks.

I express my concern-I believe it is the concern of all Australian Democrats and indeed, I suspect, of most Australians outside this Parliament-for the fact that over the next three weeks while we endure another election in New South Wales we will have more of the same. I believe that all Australians, not just the people of New South Wales, will be watching and listening to this Parliament over the next three weeks. The question will be asked whether we are going to set a new low standard of political debate for this country or whether we will rise above the gutter level politics that some honourable members and honourable senators obviously prefer. I will speak for my Party. In the New South Wales campaign there will be no dirt from the Australian Democrats. They will be debating the real issues-the quality of life issues such as hospitals, education and transport. Fortunately the Democrats do have answers. Many of these answers have been picked up by the Australian Labor Party since it came to government. I am delighted that these matters have been picked up by this Parliament. These matters similarly will be picked up by the New South Wales Parliament as a result of the election of our Upper House Leader, Ray Griffiths, who will join the Honourable Liz Kirkby in the Upper House of that Parliament after this election. We will have meaningful debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, you are getting very wide of the subject of the main issue. I ask you to refer to the actual subject of the debate.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President, I will follow your lead. In my discussions over the weekend with members of this Parliament, with honourable senators and with my constituents I felt growing disquiet at the direction that the Parliament is taking and the inordinately disproportionate amount of time being spent in debate which has no other purpose than to denigrate either people outside the Parliament or people inside the Parliament. In particular, on broadcast days parliamentarians seem to have concentrated their time and attention on the topic of tapes, taps, transcripts, corruption, and abuse of judges and justices and each other. We are currently suffering massive problems in our economy with unemployment, under-employment, redevelopment of our resources and the possible consequences of the deregulation of banking and financial institutions in this country. Surely our priorities should now turn to resolving some of these problems. I believe that the people of Australia and the majority of parliamentarians would support the Australian Democrats' attitude on this.

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. It is very good for Senator Evans to take the opportunity to open the New South Wales election campaign in this way! He has barely touched on the subject matter. Whilst I appreciate the material he is giving I do not think it has any relevance at all. I ask you to see that we get on with the discussion on the tapes.
—I have already warned Senator Evans about relevance. He must stick to the subject of the debate which is the tapes.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I have been back on that subject since you issued your correction to me. I am disappointed that Senator Archer has not recognised that. I ask, in the name of the people of Australia, who are listening to this debate and to this Parliament, that we get on with discussing the topics for which we were elected and that we let Mr Costigan, or other appropriate people, get on with the investigation of crime and corruption in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To a formal motion that the Senate take note of a ministerial statement on the Age tapes, the Opposition has moved an amendment that there be laid on the table of the Senate certain transcripts, portions of transcripts and an aide memoire of the discussions of the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) sanitised by the removal of names or other information which might identify individuals. The amendment, which I support, does not seek to make judgments about any person, any tape or any judicial figure. It does not seek to bring down an address for the removal of any judge. It does not go into that question. The amendment seeks to have brought into this Parliament information about transcripts, records of conversations and primary data sanitised to protect individuals and to protect the naming of individuals which the Senate can use. It seeks these things in a situation, as I shall describe, in which confidence in public administration in my State of New South Wales is in question.

SPEECH.PARA: What is at issue in this amendment is the determination of the Liberal and National Parties to have brought into this Parliament such information, without names, that would allow us to test or assess what is going on. The Australian Labor Party is determined to prevent that course being followed, to prevent that information coming to the Parliament and to prevent the Parliament from knowing what it needs to know in order to do its duty. If, as Senator Tate admitted, the Parliament is the arena which finally has to make up its mind, how can he and his Party logically deny to the Parliament the information and the means so to do?

Today we are seeking to have information given to the people of Australia and the Parliament, through the Senate, to allow us to determine our view. The people of New South Wales, sick of the stench of corruption in government, in the magistracy, in the police and in politics, are anxious to know the facts. I also do not understand why we are so compulsively trying to go to these lengths to make sure that we do not go round the traps. The names are clear and the offences are clear and we are doing everything we possibly can to avoid seeing them. A judge has been mentioned in several places, I find. Many questions have been asked about a judge. But I am not fully aware, yet, of whether it was the judge who first decided that he needed to test his position by contacting the Attorney-General or whether it was the Attorney-General who decided that he needed to check up on the judge. I guess, however, that whatever else may have transpired, the Attorney-General was able to get even a third legal opinion on the position of the judge.

I find, as does the general public, that this Dickensian definition of what constitutes misbehaviour is absolutely hilarious. The general public regards it as an absolute joke to find that it takes two legal definitions to decide what constitutes misbehaviour. I believe that this is what we might call a Clayton misbehaviour-the sort of misbehaviour you have when you are not having one. I do not think it requires a fancy interpretation to cloud and confuse such an issue. We now have a judge who, like his lawyer friend, came up smelling like a rose, even if it did take two or three legal opinions to get it that way. I am inclined to agree with what the Attorney-General said earlier in the afternoon. While it may to some smell like a rose it just smells like stinking fishheads to me. There seems to be no demonstrated will to do anything but at the same time there is a considerable demonstrated will to do nothing except to obtain definitions, to abuse those who have an interest in getting some action and to denigrate what information is available.

I suppose the Attorney-General's statement went about as far as it could possibly go. It is by far the firmest statement that we have had from anybody. The most powerful paragraph is on page 20. It states:

It is this Government's view that the investigation of the circumstances in which this material originated should be pursued with the greatest vigour. It is also the Government's view that if, in the course of those investigations, other illegalities are established then the law will take its course in relation to those illegalities.

They are powerful words, that is real action! It is a real, red hot, red-blooded effort to attack organised big time crime such as I have never seen before. Who could ask for anything more than that? The smokescreen is absolutely alarming. The comments of the New South Wales Premier who, like me, may well be named or alluded to for all I know, are frightening. I think it is this 'quick, everybody out' or the under-the-mat approach that is so inappropriate.

I am pleased to see that out of all this we have not overlooked the civil liberties issue. It is raised consistently, and rightly so. Everybody seems to have civil liberties now, but none more than the crooks of Australia. I wonder what the position of Donald Mackay's civil liberties is. What about the honest cops, honest judges, honest magistrates and so on? What has been mooted in the last 14 weeks since we first got onto this matter to restore their prestige? Nothing at all. What have we done to tell the public at large that their position is guaranteed and that they can have complete confidence in law enforcement and the law makers? Nothing at all. While ever we fudge it is getting harder to sell the notion that Parliament is not here to protect the crooks. While roaring about those who, against real odds, were trying to fight crime, not one thing in the 26-page document gave me any indication as to what was actually being done. Every law abiding officer, administrator and citizen wants to know what is being done. The vast majority of people are honest, decent and law abiding. I am prepared to admit that there are some that are not like that. How can we encourage people to come forward with information without fear? I am wondering whether we are really making sure that we are not getting information. The frightening position of allegations about top citizens certainly destroys public confidence.

On 30 November and 8 December I asked the Attorney-General to outline what was being done about the substance of the allegations. I would still like to know what is being done. Why does he not cancel this farce about a joint inquiry and get a fearless, responsible citizen and give him open options to investigate and report on those matters that would assist the fight against organised crime, whatever it is, irrespective of whose jurisdiction it may be under?

I suggest that the Government reads the papers. The reflection of public perception is there. The fudging is incriminating many people-names are now widely rumoured-and they must be cleared or found guilty as the case may be. The 26-page document that Senator Evans put down may salve his conscience but it does not salve anybody else's conscience. I would like to see a bit of action in this matter. I do not care who winds up in the net. I do not care about their station, their occupation, their sex or sexual preference, their political party affiliations or anything else. Even though it still seems to be escaping the Attorney-General, right round Australia people feel as I do. Like me they are wondering why both the Attorney-General and his colleague, the Premier of New South Wales, are so timid about taking action that might put the whole nasty business to rest, that would clear the innocent, restore dignity and honesty to parliament, the law and the police and give the public at large the feeling of security to which surely they are entitled. That is all we seek. (Quorum formed)

E. Humphreys, the Cross Special Commission of Inquiry--

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Attorney-General was present during Senator Baume's contribution to the debate. He did not take a point of order at that time and he now accuses Senator Baume of scurrilous muck- raking. I suggest that that is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
