—I invite the Attorney-General to come back to the subject of the debate.

—The reality of the matter is that those particular royal commissions which Senator Baume did not mention amply demonstrated, as I have said on innumerable occasions, that where there is smoke, where there are allegations of this kind, there are indeed not always fires. If the Street and Cross commissions of inquiry have demonstrated nothing else they have demonstrated that. Whether there is smoke, just smoke, or fire in the context of the present Age allegations has yet to be demonstrated. The Government has taken every step within its disposal to ensure that just that occurs. Since the Age made its allegations on 2 February the Government has acted with speed, diligence and integrity in examining and investigating this material, taking advice and setting in place appropriate investigative mechanisms as it went. Indeed, the challenge to the Government's behaviour in this respect seems to be no longer to our general handling of the affair, because it is accepted and it has to be accepted by an objective observer that the Government has acted and reacted properly and responsibly.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now witnessing by the Opposition a desperate scrabbling, clutching at straws, waiting feebly, as I said the other day, like a collection of half- starved political Micawbers for something to turn up, something which may of course be to the advantage of their political friends in New South Wales. The Government will give no aid and comfort to them in this unworthy ambition. We will act in accordance with the law. We will act in accordance with principle. We will act in accordance with common decency, and we will act with the proper and appropriate respect for the institution of the judiciary, none of which things can be said of the behaviour of the Opposition in this matter. The issue on which the Opposition has chosen to focus, in particular in its amendment moved in this debate, is the position of the judge, an issue on which the Age made an almost complete fool of itself so far as the accuracy of its own reporting is concerned, and an issue on which the Opposition at the moment is doing no better.

What the Opposition's argument boils down to, the nub essentially is this: The suggestion is that I, as Attorney-General, and the Government are defiling-or defying, I think was Senator Durack's expression-the proper role of Parliament in this particular matter; that we are relying wholly on Mr Temby and the Solicitor-General, Dr Griffith, as to the statement of the law that is relevant and applicable here; that we are relying wholly on Mr Temby's conclusions and the police conclusions so far as the application of that law to the facts is concerned. The Opposition apparently believes, and has said so over and again in this debate and in moving its amendment, that we ought not to so rely; that we should leave it to the Parliament to make its own judgment of every related issue in this particular matter and that we should give the Parliament, give the scavenging, ravaging hordes opposite, all the material necessary for the Parliament itself to do the whole job. While on the face of it that has a certain prima facie plausibility which I readily acknowledge, there are excellent reasons why it is inappropriate and indeed quite wrong in principle to go down this particular track here.

There are two basic reasons which I bring into the debate to explain why the Government has taken the course that it has. The first is that the role of the Parliament in relation to matters of alleged judicial misbehaviour is not a role which is at large. The Parliament's responsibility is not of the same order as it is in relation to scrutinising and exposing to criticism the Executive. The Parliament's role in this respect is one that is constrained by the Constitution and constrained by the law. Here the role is a limited one, and in exercising that role self-restraint is entirely necessary. What is crucial is an appreciation of the application of the principle of separation of powers and the kind of reasoning associated with that, based on the books and on the cases, which lead one inexorably to the conclusion that Parliament's only role in relation to section 72 of the Constitution is to look at misbehaviour in the conduct of judicial office, whether that takes the form of positive misbehaviour such as bias or wrongful conflicts of interest or, rather, neglect or default in the exercise of one's duty. On the other hand, it is criminal misconduct, the establishment that someone has committed all the elements of a criminal offence which by its nature is of a kind to make the person an improper continuing member of the judiciary.

It is clear that it is not appropriate to censure or to chide for so-called indiscretions or what might be thought by some people to constitute injudiciousness. Lesser steps of that kind, which it might well be appropriate for Parliament to take in relation to the Executive, are beyond the competence, beyond the capacity, beyond the responsibility of the Parliament when it comes to the judiciary. I will develop that point further in a moment. Essentially that is the first step in the argument. The Parliament's role is a very limited, very constrained, very circumscribed one for excellent reasons of constitutional and legal principle.

The second part of the argument is put on a quite different basis. Whatever the role of the Parliament might be in relation to determining questions of misbehaviour, it is not necessarily appropriate, and it is certainly not appropiate in the circumstances of this particular case, for Parliament to have available to it and publicly on the record, under cover of the privileges associated with this Parliament, all the raw material on the basis of which the Government has reached a judgment that the conditions in question are not satisfied. In an ordinary case there may well be some justification for that claim being made. Obviously, again it is a claim that is made with a degree of prima facie plausibility. But this is no ordinary case. Why is it not an ordinary case? Because even on the most favourable view of the authenticity of this material this material was squalidly and illegally obtained. There is a fundamental principle of law which in the United States is an absolute principle of law, that evidence which is illegally obtained is inadmissible. It is a familiar basis on which the courts on every day of the year exercise a discretion to exclude otherwise possibly relevant material. There are excellent reasons of principle why that is so. Moreover, it is not just illegality, it is material which involves a gross violation of personal privacy, if again it is authentic and to the extent it is authentic. It is material in respect of which, as the Australian Democrats have acknowledged quite frankly and quite openly, its authenticity is absolutely not established. Certainly it is material in respect of which its authenticity, either in whole or in part, has not been conceded by the judge in question. To table this material would be to lend the weight and credibility of the Government to it.

Sanitisation may occur but it would only take someone to drop a name-the Opposition has given every indication that that is its intention-for the whole picture to be laid out. I understand from what I hear-one never knows quite what to believe around the corridors-that it is the Opposition's intention, against the better judgment of some of its senior members, to overtly name the names in Parliament tomorrow. What a squalid little affair that will be when it occurs. I will be very interested to see the reaction of Senator Durack and a couple of others who, I am told, have argued against such a squalid course. It will only take, of course, the naming of a few names, if the material is sanitised and put on the public record by the Goverment, for the whole picture such as it is, with its authenticity still not established, to be wholly laid out. There is simply no justification for doing that.

The amendment which has been moved by the Opposition could not be complied with without taking a very significant step as a result down the road towards a spectacular and gross violation of privacy. It would not be just acknowledging that invasion as it has already occurred by the people who taped this material, if they did in the first place, not only the violation of privacy that was engaged in by the Age in conducting itself in the way in which it did, but a violation of privacy to which this Government and this Parliament would be giving aid, comfort and nourishment and support in principle. This is not a case like the bottom of the harbour legal opinions or some of the other matters which have attracted debate in the past where the names and the other identifying characteristics could be eliminated with confidence that this would protect any privacy or other considerations, in that case, considerations relating to the proper investigation of offences. Because the source of the material is as it is in this case and because of the wide circulation that that material has already had so far albeit not openly and overtly out on the public record, there simply can be no guarantee that the identifying characteristics, the names, will not be attributed by some other person outside the control of this Government to produce the very result which this motion purportedly seeks to avoid.

SPEECH.PARA: Three separate questions are involved here and they have been splendidly mixed up together in Senator Missen's contribution to this debate. It falls to me to try to untangle them quickly. The three questions are: Firstly, does Parliament or the courts, the High Court of Australia, have the last word in this matter, in this kind of issue? The second question is: Is Parliament, if it does have the last word, nonetheless obliged to act in accordance with law, legal principles and legal standards? The third question is: Assuming that, what are the proper standards which Parliament should apply and what is the proper meaning of misbehaviour? Let me address myself quickly to each of those questions because, as I say, they are quite fundamental to what this debate is all about and what this chamber's appreciation of the role of Parliament is all about in these matters.

In regard to the first question-that is, is it the case that parliament or the courts have the last word-I am prepared to concede that, on the reading of the Constitution, almost certainly the answer is that Parliament has the last word; that these matters are not justiciable; that section 72 of the Constitution means what, on the face of it, it seems to mean-that Parliament has to make the decision in praying in its address as to whether or not there has been misbehaviour. I do not exclude the possibility that in an extreme case there might be an argument for some residual justiciability. For example, were Parliament minded to move, in some more sectarian age perhaps, that all Protestants or Catholics be removed from the bench, or members of the National Civic Council for that matter, or the socialist Left, if there were some utterly irrational criterion of that kind being applied in an extreme way, it may be that some principle could be identified which would give some overriding role to the courts of law. But it is very difficult to argue that and I acknowledge the force of the arguments of Senator Missen and others that these issues are, on the face of it, just not justiciable; that Parliament does have the final word.

However-this is where most of the confusion arises-the second point is that Parliament can nonetheless be regarded as being obliged to act in accordance with ascertainable and indeed definable legal principles by references to standards which are inherent in the Constitution in deciding itself-albeit with the last word-what is permissible misbehaviour. The notion that simply because parliament has the last word-parliament can in turn apply whatever whim or fancy strikes it, just simply does not follow from the first proposition; it is quite a separate issue. The answer in this respect-and I obviously have not time now to track over the debates on the Australian Constitutional Convention and all the rest of the materials which lead one to this conclusion-is manifestly yes, that it was the intention of the founding fathers, or, as Senator Tate would prefer, the framers of the Constitution, that this be so. They understood the difference between the United Kingdom's system of interrelationships between the judiciary and the Westminster Parliament and Executive and the situation which applied in Australia with a written Constitution depending on a much more rigorous separation of powers.

Indeed, it is arguable, quite separately from what people thought they were doing when they debated the issue, based on the fundamental principles of the Constitution, that the principle of separation of powers demands that it be the case that parliament not act simply erratically but by reference to very carefully, precisely and narrowly defined standards of what is impermissible behaviour.

The third question I come to is just what are the standards. These points are partly linked together because the notion running through the second point is that it is proper for parliament to exercise some self-restraint. Simply because it might be construed as having the ultimate power does not mean that that power should be exercised in such a way that it passes judgment upon someone by reference to lesser standards than are contained in the text of the Constitution itself. So the third question becomes: What are the standards contained in the Constitution itself? If not in its expressed language-although the language of proved misbehaviour takes us some distance down the track-what is the obligation of parliament and to what ought it have regard? In this respect I can only simply say again, without having an opportunity to develop the point, that the situation is very different from that which obtains in the United Kingdom. In the United Kingdom traditionally there have been two tracks by which one could attack the judiciary. First of all the Crown, that is the government of the day, without reference to parliament, is traditionally in Britain able to remove judges for misbehaviour in the conduct of their judicial office. Secondly, it can do so by reference to misbehaviour not related to judicial office but involving convictions or possible convictions for what are called 'infamous offences'. The authority for that-and there are authorities all over the place- is Shetreet's volume Judges on Trial which most precisely and elaborately sets out the foundation for that rule as it operates in Britain.

The second track in Britain is the parliament itself. This is where I make a point which has been constantly overlooked in this debate. In Britain there is a separate track. The first two points I made about what the Crown can do are entirely familiar, because that is what has been taken over in Australia. In Britain parliament can make a judgment, can pray and make an address by reference to any standard of misbehaviour the British Parliament chooses to apply to the particular circumstances of that case. It is acknowledged as a matter of constitutional principle in the United Kingdom-ungoverned, as that is, by a written constitution; not being a federation, as it is; and not being the kind of separation-of-powers-oriented constitutional system that ours is- although it has been many years since that power was exercised, that parliament has a completely ungovernable, unfettered discretion to do what it likes. Hopefully it will exercise some self-restraint, but there is not the kind of constraint built in there as there is here.

What we took over here in Australia-and it is amply established in the literature, in the cases by the founding fathers and in their debates-was the first track. The deliberate intention of the founding fathers and the writers of the Australian Constitution, using the language, as they did, of proved misbehaviour, was to take over the traditional narrow, finite grounds of attacks upon the judiciary; to limit it, in other words, to those two categories of misbehaviour in the conduct of judicial office, either positively or negatively, or secondly, misbehaviour constituted by the commission-albeit not necessarily an actual conviction-of an offence which by its character is such as to make the continued occupancy of the Bench improper or inappropriate. Thus is there the distinction between the conviction for a parking or a driving offence on the one hand and forging a cheque or something on the other. It is that distinction that we have taken over. It is that distinction which is embodied in our law and in our practice. It is that distinction which is enshrined in the Solicitor-General 's opinion. It is that distinction which is enshrined rather more briskly in Mr Temby's opinion. It is that distinction which makes clear that the role of this Parliament is indeed very limited.

Combine that with the particular circumstances of this case, the particularly squalid character of the material at issue in this case, and, Mr President, I believe that we have an excellent foundation on which to come to and sit on the conclusion that the Government has reached in this matter; that is-based as it has been on independent verification and analysis of the material by people whose competence and integrity have not hitherto been questioned, that it is wrong for this Parliament to embark upon the kind of adventure that is contained and enshrined in the amendment which the Opposition urges upon us.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, let me say this: I totally concur with Senator Chaney as does my Party and, I believe, to some grudging extent, Senator Gareth Evans, that the question of whether the judge named had misbehaved is not a subject to be determined by lawyers, no matter how smart or how well credentialled they are. Therefore one can say that Senator Chaney formulated a perfectly respectable argument when he said that if Parliament is to be the arbiter of the behaviour of this judge then the Parliament should have all the documents that were made available to Messrs Temby and Griffith. The fact is that we do not have all the documents. We have had put to us through the medium of a newspaper certain purported transcripts of tapes that are alleged to be in existence.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we read them. Some of us-Senator Tate and I, for example-have deliberately not read them.

—That is the honourable senator's problem, with great respect. I have read every one of them. Therefore one can find great sympathy with what the Liberals are putting. Because this is such a fundamental point the Democrats believe it has to be debated, not in the heat of a tawdry State election campaign but after that campaign is out of the way, when the currency of these tapes will not have lost any value or any thrust. Can somebody tell me why there is a burning need to have those tapes divulged this week and not in the week the Senate resumes?
—Because the Attorney-General will not investigate them any further. He has shut them off altogether.

—I am sorry, I cannot quite follow that, with great respect. If that material is made available to the Parliament, and I have already conceded that the Parliament has to make this decision, surely the credibility of the Parliament's decision will be better among the general public if the determination of the matter is made out of the context of a tawdry State election campaign. If Senator Missen, for whom I have a great admiration in these matters, cannot see that point, I cannot put it any more clearly. I am sorry that I cannot explain it to his satisfaction. On the other hand, the public production of those tapes at this stage could do incalculable wilful mischief to possibly innocent people.
—But not in a month's time, is that what you are saying?

—Senator Durack during his tenancy as Attorney-General was a champion of the protection of civil liberties and personal reputations. I pay him credit for that. I cannot understand his new enthusiasm in this area. There may be allegations on these naked transcripts of tapes. There could be an argument that they should be divulged for the reason I just gave, namely, that the Parliament ought to be in possession of the information. I would be tempted to vote for the Liberal Party's amendment in its original form if I could be guaranteed that the personalities would not be divulged or had not been divulged . Let us stop kidding ourselves. I ask the innocents in this chamber, the babes in the wood such as my friend Senator Baden Teague, to put up their hands now to indicate that they do not know the name of the judge. I wish that the Parliament were now being televised. I ask the original babe in the wood, Senator Withers: Does he not know the name of the judge?
—Order! Will Senator Chipp address the Chair.

—Mr President, do you not know the name of the judge? Do you not know the name of the solicitor? This whole thing is a joke. Is there one member of the Press Gallery who does not know the name of the judge, the solicitor, or all the names on the tapes? Of course they do. As soon as this information in its naked and unadorned form comes down the glossary anonymously will appear in the Press Gallery or it will be laid on the table here. A name will be put down to fit the name of the judge. A name will be put down to fit the name of every character in those tapes. If each of those characters were guilty of some offence I would not mind at all naming criminals or friends of criminals. But here we have an opportunity of finding people guilty by association under parliamentary privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Federal judge has been guilty of misbehaviour, not just misbehaviour in terms of the strict meaning of section 72 of the Constitution, but guilty of misbehaviour in a sense that will compromise his position as a judge, that is the point that worries me, that a strict legal interpretation of his behaviour might not offend section 72 but could well put him in a situation with his associations with organised crime-it would make it impossible for him to carry out his position without fear or favour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, for God's sake!
—Mr President, with your indulgence, I pause to ask Senator Evans: Why does he say 'for God's sake'?
—Because there is absolutely no foundation for any such suggestion on the basis of that material. For God's sake, don't destroy someone.
—Order!

—Mr President, I respect Senator Evans's interjection. This is the very point that Senator Durack, Senator Chaney and I are making. I am not prepared simply to take Senator Evans's opinion, distinguished lawyer though he is, that 'for God's sake, it will not compromise the judge's position'. I believe that the Parliament should make that decision. I do not want to equate the alleged behaviour of a judge with the proven and confessed behaviour of a Minister of the Crown some years ago in the British Parliament. At that time, that Minister of the British Parliament committed a series of grave indiscretions. It was not the fact that he committed those indiscretions, which were not illegal, that forced him to resign. It was the fact that those indiscretions compromised him as far as the proper conduct of his duties was concerned.
—Profumo.
—Indeed.
—What about Parkinson?

—I will rest with Profumo. I think that is enough on which to rest my case. Nevertheless, I thank Senator Withers for his assistance. Indeed, I am grateful to Senator Withers because Profumo was involved in another indiscretion of misleading the House which Parkinson did not. I thank Senator Withers; his interjection has greatly improved the content of my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, what is the result of the amendment of the Australian Democrats? I will read it out to the listening public to see whether they can find anything exceptionable about the motion as the Democrats would have it amended. I understand that the Liberal Party will vote against this amendment and the Australian Labor Party will vote for it. We will then go through the charade after the amendment has been passed, as it will be, of the Labor Party voting against the whole deal. This is how the Democrats would like to see the amendment:

and that there be laid upon the Table of the Senate without delay all those transcripts or parts of transcripts of authenticated and genuine tapes which refer to any conversation between the judge and the solicitor or other conversations referring to the judge or in which he participated, together with the aide-memoire of the Attorney-General's discussions with the judge on February 15 and 24, subject to the deletion from all documents of any name or identifying characteristics of individuals.

To those honourable senators who have interjected-Senator Walters, Senator Lewis and those other rampant Liberals on my right-we make no apology whatsoever for inserting the words 'authenticated and genuine', because we believe that the least this Parliament can demand is that the good and innocent names of people should not be desecrated by rumour or by edited tapes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to reopen the general debate on this matter. I take it that what the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has done is, in effect, close the debate. In regard to matters which he has raised I just want to say that a number of the things he has said have clarified the situation and I think have acknowledged the areas which we have been debating this afternoon. Obviously we are miles apart on the question of whether we took over from Britain a rigid idea that only two or three things might be described as misbehaviour. On that question I think we stand entirely in disagreement. The Parliament is not so restricted. He concedes that it is a matter for the Parliament to make final decisions. Of course it is a matter for the Parliament to be responsible, to regard it as a very serious matter and not act with any gay abandon or just for political purposes. We on this side of the House disagree entirely with the interpretation which the Solicitor-General and the Attorney-General have put before the Parliament and say that parliament has a wide discretion and parliament must exercise it in its own interests. This was intended by the founders of the Constitution-that it should have its mind directed to these matters of misbehaviour and that it should seriously control its own destiny in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something not open to that debate because on that matter we obviously fundamentally agree. I want to say something about the amendment of the Australian Democrats. It seems to me that the Democrats, probably with the best of intentions-I will give them that-have fallen into a real trap. They recognise that the Australian Labor Party-the Government-will support this amendment. Of course it will, so that it can therefore ruin the Opposition's amendment. Look at the language of the amendment. What does it require the Government to do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Requiring authenticity and genuineness. What a travesty! What a sham!

—The Attorney-General may well smile because he knows that he can easily deal with that. If he were to lay upon the table of the Senate without any delay those transcripts, or parts of transcripts of authenticated and genuine tapes and so forth-he would have no intention of authenticating those transcripts and tapes because he has decided--
—The inquiry is still on.
—No, the honourable senator is wrong; the inquiry has not suggested that the judge's conversations will be considered any further. That has been wiped out.
—The joint inquiry is still on.
—The inquiry is in regard to all the other matters.
—It is not; it is still on.

—The honourable senator should read the statement again. He will see that the Attorney-General has said: 'There is nothing in this matter with the judge and we are not going on with that'. The Government is going to bother about the authentication of the tapes in regard to the judge. It is not going to table anything.
—The tapes are with an expert at the moment.
—Yes, the tapes are being looked at and we do not know what will come from that. I have no idea what the State and Federal police forces may do or what they will come up with.
—You should have found out.

—I cannot find out because we will not know that until they report back. They might report back to us and I think they should. I think this Parliament, in due course, will have to set up a committee in both Houses to have a look at the evidence.
—This is about the right time to do it.
—This will take some time.
—Order! Senator Missen, I ask you to address the Chair.
—Mr President, I will direct my remarks through you.
—This is a serious matter.

—This is a serious matter involving a Federal judge and, therefore, is not a matter in which the Government can say: 'We say there is nothing else in these allegations. We are not going to look into them further'. The Government is not going to do anything further and say that the tapes are authenticated or genuine tapes in respect of that judge. The Government will not be concerned further with the matter and, therefore, the responsibility comes back to this Parliament, to this chamber, to ensure that we know what evidence has been obtained and what has been done in regard to those tapes and that, if necessary, we pursue other inquiries. We must do that.
—Which one of us can prove that they are authenticated tapes? Which parliamentarian do you suggest?
—I am not suggesting anyone. The honourable senator has been here for one year and he is not aware of the fact that Senate committees are able to obtain evidence and are able to get consultants.
—You didn't suggest a committee.
—I think this will happen in the long term.
—Order! There is a nice little conversation going on up there, but we cannot hear you down here.

—I am sorry, Mr President. I will ignore the five-finger exercise over here. This Senate obviously will have to investigate this matter. Even if the Government and the Attorney-General are not willing to do that in respect of the judge we will have to do it. It is our obligation and the public expects it. As Senator Chipp has said, the public is very concerned at the amount of muck- raking that goes on, particularly in New South Wales, within the Parliaments and so forth and we have to avoid that, but we do have to investigate the matter.
—Tell that to your leader tonight.

—Of course the honourable senator is conducting his own mini- Watergate here and endeavouring to ensure that these matters are not looked into . This Parliament has to look into them. I say to the Australian Democrats that their amendment is such as to completely vitiate any usefulness of the Opposition amendment. Therefore, the Government says that it will support the amendment and then defeat the whole matter. It will not be the end of the matter , but it means that we will not be pursuing and taking on further--
—Yes, we will adjourn the debate until after the New South Wales election. We will support that.

—The Government will not have that. We will find that there will be no investigation. It is necessary for a discussion to be had and for this matter to be investigated. The Australian Democrats are holding it up at the moment and avoiding the tabling of the documents which the Government is not prepared to use. I suggest that the Australian Democrats amendment is, therefore , an act of folly.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Haines's amendment to Senator Durack's proposed amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: 'That the words proposed to be inserted by Senator Haines's amendment to Senator Durack's proposed amendment be inserted'.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: 'That the words proposed to be added to the motion by Senator Durack's amendment, as amended by Senator Haines's amendment, be added'.
—The Opposition no longer supports the amendment in the form in which it has been put by the--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. On what basis is Senator Chaney now addressing the Senate? He is still speaking to the amendment which is before the Senate.
—Mr President, I have never spoken to the motion. I spoke only to the Australian Democrats' amendment.

—It was understood that the Leader of the Opposition was speaking to the whole debate when he spoke. During his remarks, after he had been speaking for about 10 or 15 minutes, he referred to the amendment moved by Senator Haines. He is entitled to seek leave to speak.

—As I recall, Mr President, I rose to speak to an amendment to Senator Durack's amendment which had been moved by Senator Haines. I explained why the Opposition would not support Senator Haines's amendment. Senator Haines' s amendment has now been carried and we now have before us an amended proposal from Senator Durack.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition did not indicate at the time he spoke that he was speaking in the manner in which he has now indicated. He was taken as speaking to the whole debate.
—Mr President, I have no wish to canvass your ruling. I seek leave to make a brief explanation.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—Thank you, Mr President. I thank the Senate for its indulgence. The Opposition does not support the amendment in the form in which it has now been left. The reason for that has been made clear, but I would like it to be beyond doubt. The Opposition does not regard the amendment in the form in which it now appears as putting any obligation on the Government which is really enforceable against the Government or which gives the Parliament, the Opposition or the Australian people any guarantee that the Government will perform in an appropriate way. The fact is that the decision as to what is authenticated and genuine will be left to this Government. The Opposition can come back to this matter when the New South Wales election is out of the way and we can see whether the Democrats will put their money where their mouths are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There are principled grounds for opposing the amendment in the form in which it now exists. They are those which I foreshadowed in my previous speech. But in case there should be any confusion or doubt about the Government's position on this matter, let me make it clear that while Senator Haines's amendment, as carried, represented an infinite improvement on the Opposition's amendment, it was still subject to all sorts of problems which I outlined previously. As to the tape and transcript material, as I indicated, even if it does prove to be genuine and authenticated, there are still very real difficulties about putting on the public record material which is illegally obtained and which amounts to a gross invasion of privacy. It is quite unprecedented for criminal investigations of this kind to be put into the public domain in circumstances like this, and it is not a precedent that the Government would wish to see established in this or any other case.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the second part of the amendment in the form in which it still exists-the question about the production of the aide-memoire-I made it perfectly clear in my previous speech that there were, again, grounds of principle related to the confidentiality of communications between the Government-the Attorney-General in particular-and judges combined, of course, with considerations of privacy and fairness to the judge in question so far as the textual substance of this material is concerned. For that reason, the production of the document would have been resisted and is now still resisted. So for reasons which I hope are understood by the Democrats, not to mention everybody else, we will also vote against the amendment.

That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment as amended by Senator Haines's amendment) be added.
