That is the truth of the matter. The Russian Navy constantly patrols the Indian Ocean. I believe from that point of view alone and recognising the cynical and stupid expression on Senator Grimes's face that he does not recognise its significance to Australia. I can alter what I am saying to make it even more significant. South Africa is on one side of the Indian Ocean and Australia is on the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australia.

—Yes. It is of tremendous strategic importance to the security of Australia and for the security of the western world. What aggravates me is that SWAPO and ANC are financially and militarily supported by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The USSR would love to grab hold of South Africa, even if it was for only a few months because of the strategic materials that are available in that country. It could build nuclear weapons. Heaven knows what it would use against the free world of which we are a significant part.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Townley said earlier, it is not too late for the Government of Australia to refuse to bend to the dictates of the extreme left wing of the Australian Labor Party epitomised by the action taken by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr West. It is not too late to demonstrate that the consensus view of Australia, the thing that our Prime Minister is now world famous for, should prevail. I challenge the Government to recognise that the majority of people in Australia are offended by what this Government has done. It will do no harm to the Government of Australia to listen to the elected representatives of other countries about current political events about which they should be better informed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a long evening. I will correct a couple of points that were made by previous speakers before I talk on the issue with which we are concerned at the moment. Senator Townley suddenly brought into the debate the matter of gap insurance, of all things. I point out to Senator Townley and the lady he quoted that in 1975 and again in 1979 the Australian Medical Association very vigorously opposed gap insurance because it believed that good medical care could not be provided unless someone crosses the palm with silver. It believed that very firmly. Senator Townley's pensioner patient may not believe it but it happens to be what the medical profession believes. I believe that if Senator Townley is defending the medical profession, he ought to get his facts straight.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne in passing spoke about the President of the Senate going to South Africa. I hope that on some future occasion Senator Crichton- Browne will apologise to the President on that matter. Senator Jessop, I think, and certainly Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Townley, quoted Voltaire.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not.
—I am sorry; the other two quoted Voltaire. Voltaire said:

SPEECH.PARA: I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.

I point out that any black person in South Africa who tries to carry on the way Opposition senators carry on and who tries to oppose the policy of the South African Government is very likely to be sentenced to death. That is what this debate is about. Senator Jessop talks about people coming to this country who are elected in free democratic elections. Two million whites in South Africa elect the member of the National Party who was to come here. The member of the Presidential Council who was to come here is not elected. Nineteen million people in South Africa have no vote at all. Yet honourable senators opposite talk about a free and democratic society. They do not know what a free and democratic society is. The simple fact of the matter is that Senator Jessop has had at least four free trips to South Africa, paid for by the South African Government, and he has been swanned around the country by that Government all that time. Having been duchessed, he comes back and says: 'It is a lovely country. It is a free and democratic country.' He is a paid agent of the South African Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order--
—I withdraw, Mr President.
—He does not know what he is withdrawing, Mr President.
—I withdraw.

—The point is that Senator Grimes said that Senator Jessop was a paid agent of the South African Government. I object to that kind of thing being said in one of the snide comments which Senator Grimes is becoming well known throughout this country for making in the Senate. I feel that not only should he be made to withdraw but that also that kind of remark should be struck from the record of the Senate.
—I take it that Senator Grimes has already withdrawn the phrase: ' He is a paid agent of the South African Government'.
—I withdraw. I said that Senator Jessop had had several trips to South Africa at the expense of the South African Government.
—You said four.

—Maybe it is four. Is it three, or only two? Let us hear the number. The simple fact of the matter is that the two gentlemen who sought visas to Australia, Mr Durr and Mr Rajab, were to come here, in the words of the South African Ambassador, Dr Worrall, 'for confidential seminars'. Senator Crichton- Browne tells us that they are to be confidential only so that the Press will not report them, so that it will not cause trouble in this country. What a lot of nonsense. They were asked to come here to speak at confidential seminars on behalf of the South African Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1975 the Liberal-Country Party Government was elected. In 1983 that Government was defeated. In all that time no South African members of parliament sought visas to come to this country. They did not do so because they knew that they would be refused by the previous Government. In all that time-seven years- they did not seek visas to come into this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a shame on us.

—As Senator Withers says, it is a shame on us. They did not come into this country because they knew they would be refused, because the previous Government-God forbid that I defend the previous Prime Minister-was opposed to apartheid. The previous Prime Minister said: 'We will not have sporting contacts with South Africa.' Once the Labor Government is elected, we get a try-on. They decide that they will try to come here, knowing quite well that Senator Townley, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Jessop will get up in this chamber and defend their right to do so. They never tried to come here while the previous Government was in power.
—Never did what?

—They never tried to come into this country in these circumstances. They never tried to get a visa to do so. So do not condemn the present Government for carrying through policies which the previous Government would have carried through. Do not come into this chamber and talk about a free and democratic society when in that free and democratic society two million out of 21 million people have a vote. Do not come into this place and condemn this country. Honourable senators opposite should not condemn their own country when in that country people can be locked up on Robben Island and left there for years. Let not Senator Jessop come into this place and say that the problems in Soweto are due to a couple of tribal differences, when the people in Soweto are confined there by the laws of that country, when they cannot move out of that suburb of Johannesburg because of the laws of that country. Do not say that is the fault of the people who live there. Do not say that is is the fault of the people who are confined there in sub-standard accommodation, as Senator Jessop knows they are.
—Why are other black people trying to get into South Africa rather than out of it?

—Let not Senator Townley come into this chamber and say that the 19 million black people in South Africa are all wrong and that they like to be dominated by the two million white people in that country. The simple fact of the matter is that this country, under Liberal, Country Party and Labor governments, has opposed the apartheid policy of the South African Government. We have opposed sporting contacts with that Government. We have said that we will not have people such as Danie Craven out here. Surely it is sensible that we do not have members of parliament from South Africa-one of whom is a National Party member and the other who is not an elected member-coming out here and attending proceedings which, in the words of Dr Denis Worrall, 'will be . . . confidential . . . There will . . . be no media coverage.'

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators should not condemn this Government for taking the same attitude as the previous Government to these people. They should not condemn this Government for taking a different attitude to that taken by Senator Townley , Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Jessop. I exclude carefully Senator Hill and Senator Missen from that attitude. Let us remember that in recent years in this country we have had a policy whereby we abhor apartheid. I know that there are some people on the Opposition benches who enjoy their free trips to South Africa, enjoy being looked after and swanned around by the South African Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your colleagues who go to Russia on free trips with the Australian Government?
—And to Red China?
—Honourable senators will never hear me get up in this place and defend the system which exists in Russia or in Red China.
—Do you condemn your colleagues who have gone there on free trips?
—I never do. I condemn those people who get up and uncritically support the system which exists in those countries, as those three honourable senators opposite have done.
—I have not.

—Of course the honourable senator has. I urge the honourable senator not to take on the present Government at a late hour like this for following through a policy that the previous Government had. The honourable senator knows that that is so. He knows the reason no such visas were requested by the South African Government when the previous Government was in power was that it knew they would be refused. This is a try-on. The honourable senator knows that is is a try-on. Had the previous Government, when it was in power, refused such visas, the honourable senator would not have made such a speech. He knows that he would not have done so. He would not have used the phoney arguments he has used tonight. He has had his fun on the adjournment. He has enjoyed his time and he has justified the trips he has had.
—I have not had one trip. I have not been to South Africa.
—Well, the trips that the honourable senator will get.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. It ought to be ensured that there is in the Hansard record not only the accusation that Senator Crichton-Browne enjoyed his trips to South Africa but also the denial that he has had a trip to South Africa. It seems to me that it is fair that it should appear clearly, and I simply take the point of order to make sure that it does.
—There is no point of order.
—I think it is a reasonable point of order actually, Mr President , because I realise that, had Senator Rae had trips to South Africa, he would not have been influenced in this way.
—You do yourself a disservice.
—I am not doing myself a disservice at all.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you have spoken already.

—The honourable senator has spoken and he has accused the President of doing certain things which he did not do. The honourable senator should remember that we spend a lot of time in this place debating all sorts of issues, but three out of four speakers in this debate-and I include Senator Hill -made impassioned pleas to justify people coming to this country to support the most iniquitous system in the world, a system which exists in the most horrendous way on the basis of the colour of people's skin and on the basis of where they were born and a system which has been condemned by all governments in this country, whether they be Labor or Liberal-National Party. This Government continues to oppose that sort of system. It opposes that system by refusing visas to two people who obviously were being brought out here for purely propaganda purposes. It is as simple as that. We will continue to oppose that sort of thing. We will continue to look at applications for visas such as this on an individual basis, as we should. We should not make general and sweeping condemnations, as we do not in the sporting context. The sooner the people of this country realise that amongst the majority of this Parliament there is basic agreement, the better we will all be.
—I would like the Minister to table the paper from which he quoted, if it is his wish.
—I will certainly table it. There are three pages of scribbled notes I made while the honourable senator was speaking.
—I mean the document the Minister purports to be the circular regarding the seminars.
—Does the honourable senator wish me to table the letter from the South African Ambassador inviting people to various seminars?
—Yes. I believe the Minister misquoted it, and that is why I ask that it be tabled.
—I will certainly table that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, can you guide me? I claim to have been misrepresented. Should I make a personal explanation now or following Senator Peter Rae's comments?
—If the honourable senator claims to have been personally misrepresented, he can speak now.

—First of all, let me clear up one matter. I think I did say in the course of my speech that you, Mr President, had visited South Africa. If that is not true, I withdraw it. I do not apologise because I do not believe it is anything to apologise about. I understand that you were in fact granted a visa to South Africa. I am sure that you did not receive a visa to South Africa to go somewhere else. I just set the record straight. I am sorry if I misrepresented the facts in a precise sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes commented that tonight I support everything that the South African Government has done and that I support apartheid. That is thoroughly untrue. Senator Grimes knows that it is untrue. It is regrettable that he continues to lower the quality of his speeches by introducing elements of misleading and untrue statements into them. I did not on one occasion seek to defend the South African Government. I sought only to condemn the Australian Labor Party Government for choosing not to grant visas to two members of the South African Government. Notwithstanding the fact that such applications are considered on merit, it has now been said to us by Senator Grimes that these applications were thrown out because they were a test case. If I sought to support many of the things that the South African Government seeks to do-the direction in which it is moving, its new and innovative policies and its new Constitution-I could speak for a considerable period, if I wished. But I do not support apartheid, and during my speech I did not support everything that occurs in South Africa, any more than I support everything that occurs in Australia or any other country, whether or not it be a democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had intended to move for the tabling of the document, but may I very briefly say that I hope that the Senate never reaches the stage where the fact that a member of the Parliament of this country accepts an invitation to visit another country is taken as being an acceptance of every policy. If we reach that stage we have probably gone too far towards paranoia. I thank you, Mr President, for the opportunity to add that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My name was mentioned during the debate. I should mention that I have never been to South Africa. The fact is that when I was going to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in Nairobi last October it was originally intended that I should go to Nairobi via an overnight stop in Johannesburg rather than fly through Singapore, Bombay and the Seychelles. I eventually found out that by leaving a day later I could go to Nairobi via Harare, and this I did with a member of the Opposition who was on the same aircraft. As for having been invited to attend some seminar, I assure the Senate that, as far as I know, I have never received such an invitation.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Taiwan and Australia planning to set up a non-governmental trade co- operation committee to enhance commercial relations between the two countries?
(2) Does the Federal Government sanction an improvement in commercial relations between Taiwan and Australia?
(3) What effect would upgrading commercial ties with Taiwan have on trade and diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government understands that the Australian Chamber of Commerce has been exploring the feasibility of establishing a body to enhance commercial relations between Australia and the Province of Taiwan. Australia recognises the People's Republic of China as the sole legal government of China, and acknowledges the position of the Chinese Government that Taiwan is a province of China.

(2) The arrangements establishing diplomatic relations between Australia and China in December 1972 preclude any possibility of the Australian Government establishing a trade office or any official presence in the Province of Taiwan. However, this does not preclude private organisations from doing business with the Province of Taiwan or establishing trade promotion bodies to enhance commercial relations between Australia and Taiwan.

(3) The importance the Government attaches to Australia's trade and diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China was clearly underlined during the Prime Minister's recent visit to the People's Republic. An increase in normal commercial ties with the Province of Taiwan should not in our view adversely affect these important links.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who authorised the appointment of 369 new recruits presently undergoing training in anticipation of the proposed assets test program.
(2) When were they appointed.
(3) How many of the 113 other officers currently working on the proposed assets test program were:
(a) existing departmental officers; and
(b) new appointments.
(4) In which State and Territory are the 482 officers located.
(5) In which State were the new officers appointed.
(6) Was Public Service Board approval sought for the appointment of new staff to work on the proposed assets test program; if so, when was approval:
(a) sought; and
(b) granted.
(7) What is the total number of officers that the Public Service Board has approved for the Department of Social Security to work on the proposed assets test program.
(8) How many of the new recruits are:
(a) temporary; and
(b) permanent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision to introduce an income and assets test was taken by Cabinet as part of its Budget considerations. It is normal practice, where a substantial lead time is necessary to implement government decisions, for departments to begin planning at the earliest possible date. The recruitment of the 369 new officers (to 14 December 1983) was approved by delegated officers in the Department's State administrations and was possible under the flexibility given to the Department through the use of existing average staffing arrangements.
(2) They were appointed in October, November and December.
(3) All of the 113 other officers working on the income and assets test at 14 December 1983 were existing departmental officers.
(4) The 482 officers as at 14 December 1983 were located as follows:
New South Wales 19 Victoria 165 Queensland 98 South Australia 125 Western Australia 15 Tasmania 22 Northern Territory 2 Australian Capital Territory 36
(5) New officers were appointed in Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania.

(6) The Department submitted a proposal to the Public Service Board on 21 October 1983 seeking approval to staffing levels for the income and assets test. The Department's recruitment to January 1984 was approved on 28 December 1983. Approval for the planned February and March recruitment was given on 2 February 1984.
(7) The Public Service Board approved recruitment of 2237 officers. This included 530 in respect of March 1984 but the Department will not now recruit this number.
(8) All of the 369 new recruits referred to in question (1) were permanent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers are involved in the income and assets test hotline.
(2) How many are:
(a) temporary officers; and
(b) permanent officers.
(3) How many of these officers are new recruits.
(4) When were they appointed.
(5) Who authorised their appointment.
(6) Under what vote are they being paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 27 February 1984, 19 staff are involved in the income and assets test hotline. However, both the number of staff involved and the regularity of their involvement vary from time to time depending on enquiry loads.
(2) This number includes:

(3) Only the temporary officer is a new recruit.
(4) The officer was appointed on 9 January 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: On what other occasions have funds for a program been made out of one vote and held against another to be reimbursed at a later date in the way that the Minister described in the Senate on 15 December 1983 in relation to asset testing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: None, for the reason that no appropriation of the nature of that made under Division 312 in 1983-84 has been made in prior years. However, there are some similarities between the application of funds under Division 312 and of funds issued from the Advance to the Minister for Finance in respect of requirements not fore- seen prior to introduction of the additional estimates appropriations.

Departments have been instructed to absorb to the maximum extent possible within Budget provisions additional costs arising in relation to government programs and to make application for funds from Division 312 when full absorption is not possible.
The application is to indicate the head of expenditure to which funds should be charged pursuant to Section 7 of the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84.
These instructions, in effect, confirm the correctness of charging to the normal head of expenditure, payments which later will in whole or in part, be covered by a final charge against Division 312.
